verse.text: [note]1[/note]In the third year of the reign of Jehoiakim the king of Judah [xref]a[/xref]Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon came to Jerusalem and besieged it.
verse.note: The book of Daniel concerns the destiny of Israel apportioned out by God, the contents of the seventy weeks ([link]9:24-27[/link]). It also concerns human government from Nimrod to Antichrist. Because Israel and human government are for Christ, this book also reveals certain aspects of Christ, who is the center and the circumference, the centrality and the universality, of God's move. In particular, it reveals Christ's death ([link]9:25-26[/link]), His appearing in His second coming ([link]2:34-35[/link], [link]45[/link]), His receiving dominion and a kingdom ([link]7:13-14[/link]), His being the companion of the suffering witnesses of God ([link]3:23-25[/link]), and His excellency ([link]10:4-9[/link]).[br/][br/]The central thought of Daniel is that the ruling of the heavens ([link]4:26[/link]), i.e., of the God of the heavens ([link]2:37[/link], [link]44[/link]), over all human government on earth matches God's eternal economy so that Christ would terminate the old creation for the germination of the new creation and would smash and crush the aggregate of human government and establish the eternal kingdom of God.

verse.text: And the Lord gave Jehoiakim the king of Judah into his hand with some of the [xref]a[/xref]vessels of the house of God; and he brought them into the land of [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Shinar to the house of his god, and he brought the [note]2[/note]vessels into the treasury of his god.
verse.note: The origin of Babylon was Babel in the land of Shinar, which is Chaldea ([link]Gen. 11:2[/link], [link]9[/link], [link]28[/link]; [link]Dan. 1:1-2[/link], [link]4[/link]). For the children of Israel to be taken captive to Babylon means that they were captured back to the place of the worship of idols ([link]Jer. 50:1[/link], [link]38[/link]), i.e., back to Babel, to the original place where their forefather Abraham had worshipped idols ([link]Josh. 24:2-3[/link]). Abraham was called by God out of Chaldea to Canaan to worship God ([link]Acts 7:2-4[/link]). By this, the worship of the unique God, which had been lost through Adam's fall, was resumed ([link]Gen. 12:5-8[/link]). Eventually, because of their degradation God's people were taken back to the very place out of which Abraham had been called. See notes 1[sup]1[/sup], par. 1, and 15[sup]1[/sup] in [link]Jer. 50[/link].

In the deportation to Babylon the testimony of God's elect in the worship of the unique God, Jehovah, was utterly destroyed by the carrying of some of the vessels of the temple of God into the land of Shinar and the putting of these vessels into the temple of idols ([link]2 Chron. 36:6-7[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Then the king told Ashpenaz, the chief of his eunuchs, to [xref]a[/xref]bring some of the sons of Israel, including some from the royal seed and from the nobility,
verse.note: Daniel is a book of the divine revelation concerning God's economy (see note [link]4[sup]3[/sup], par. 1, in 1 Tim. 1[/link]). In [link]chs. 1-6[/link] this book presents God's economy not in theology or in teaching but in a series of six cases as illustrations to show what God's economy is and how God's economy can be carried out.

verse.text: Children in whom was no defect, [i]who were[/i] good in appearance, who showed insight in all [xref]a[/xref]wisdom, understanding in knowledge, and apprehension in thought, and in whom was the ability to stand in the king's palace. And [i]he told him[/i] to teach them the learning and [note]1[/note]language of the Chaldeans.
verse.note: I.e., a dialect of Akkadian used by the wise men of Babylon (cf. [link]2:2[/link]).

verse.text: And the king appointed to them a daily portion from the king's [note]1[/note]choice provision and from the wine that he drank, and [i]appointed[/i] that they should be brought up for three years so that at the end [note]2[/note]of the time they might [xref]a[/xref]stand before the king.
verse.note: Nebuchadnezzar's devilish temptation was first to seduce the four brilliant young descendants of God's defeated elect, Daniel and his three companions, to be defiled by partaking of his unclean food, food offered to idols. The king's choice provision was defiling, unclean, for it had been offered to Nebuchadnezzar's gods. For Daniel and his companions to eat that food would have been to take in the defilement, to take in the idols, and thus to become one with Satan (cf. [link]1 Cor. 10:19-21[/link]). In principle, this was a temptation to eat the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, which joins man to Satan (cf. [link]Gen. 3:1-6[/link]). When Daniel and his companions refused to eat Nebuchadnezzar's unclean food and chose instead to eat vegetables ([link]vv. 8-16[/link]), in principle they rejected the tree of the knowledge of good and evil and took the tree of life, which caused them to be one with God (cf. [link]Gen. 2:9[/link], [link]16-17[/link]).
Lit., of them; referring to the years.

verse.text: Now among these from the sons of Judah were [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah.
verse.note: In his devilish tempting of Daniel and his companions, Nebuchadnezzar also changed their names, which indicated that they belonged to God, to names that made them one with idols ([link]vv. 6-7[/link]). The name Daniel, meaning God is my Judge, was changed to Belteshazzar, meaning the prince of Bel, or the favorite of Bel ([link]Isa. 46:1[/link]); the name Hananiah, meaning Jah has graciously given, or favored of Jah, was changed to Shadrach, meaning enlightened by the sun god; the name Mishael, meaning Who is what God is? was changed to Meshach, meaning Who can be like the goddess Shach? and the name Azariah, meaning Jah has helped, was changed to Abed-nego, meaning the faithful servant of the fire god Nego.

verse.text: And the leader of the eunuchs gave them names: he gave Daniel [i]the name[/i] [xref]a[/xref]Belteshazzar; Hananiah, [i]the name[/i] [xref]b[/xref]Shadrach; Mishael, [i]the name[/i] Meshach; and Azariah, [i]the name[/i] Abed-nego.

But Daniel [note]1[/note]set his heart not to [xref]a[/xref]defile himself with the king's choice provision and with the wine that [note]2[/note]the king drank, so he requested of the leader of the eunuchs that he might not defile himself.
verse.note: Daniel fought the battle by countering the devil's temptation with bold rejection ([link]vv. 8-13[/link]). God honored Daniel's fighting ([link]vv. 14-20[/link]), and Daniel and his companions became the overcomers among the remnant of God's defeated elect. Because of the captivity of God's elect in Babylon, apparently God was defeated in His interests on earth. Actually, He preserved His worship and testimony through the young overcomers. The elect were defeated, but the young overcomers were victorious. Their victory was God's victory. Because of this victory God could boast to Satan that in the midst of Babylon, God still had some overcomers who were victorious over Satan's devices. Eventually, it was through the overcomers among God's captured elect, such as Daniel and his companions, that God was able to turn the age and bring a remnant of His captured people back to the land of Canaan (see note [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Kings 19[/link]).
Lit., he.

verse.text: And God granted Daniel [xref]a[/xref]favor and compassion in the sight of the leader of the eunuchs;

And the leader of the eunuchs said to Daniel, I fear my lord the king, who has appointed your food and drink; for why should he see your faces being more morose than [i]those of[/i] the children who are of your own age? Then you would bring guilt upon my head before the king.
Then Daniel said to the steward whom the leader of the eunuchs had appointed over Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah,
Please test your servants for [xref]a[/xref]ten days, and let vegetables be given to us to eat and water to drink.
Then let our countenances be watched in your presence, as well as the countenances of the children who eat the king's choice provision; and do with your servants according to what you see.
So he listened to them in this matter and tested them for ten days.
And at the end of ten days their countenances appeared better, and they were more fully fleshed than all the children who ate the king's choice provision.
Therefore the steward withheld their [i]portion of[/i] the choice provision and the wine that they were to drink and gave them vegetables.
Now as for these four children, God gave them knowledge and insight in all learning and [xref]a[/xref]wisdom; and Daniel had understanding in all [xref]b[/xref]visions and dreams.
Then at the end of the days when the king had said that [i]the children[/i] should be brought in, the leader of the eunuchs brought them in before Nebuchadnezzar;
And the king spoke with them. And among them all none were found like Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah; therefore they stood in the presence of the king.
And in every matter of wisdom and understanding that the king inquired of them, he found them ten times better than all the magicians and conjurers who were in all his realm.
And Daniel continued until the [note]1[/note]first year of [xref]a[/xref]Cyrus the king.
verse.note: God blessed Daniel with longevity, so that he lived through the captivity of seventy years ([link]Jer. 25:11[/link]) and saw the release and return of the captives beginning from the first year of Cyrus, the king of Persia, after the fall of Babylon ([link]v. 21[/link]; [link]6:28[/link]; [link]Ezra 1:1-5[/link]).

verse.text: And in the second year of the reign of Nebuchadnezzar, Nebuchadnezzar dreamed dreams and his spirit was [xref]a[/xref]troubled and his [xref]b[/xref]sleep left him.
And the king ordered the call for the [xref]a[/xref]magicians, conjurers, sorcerers, and the Chaldeans to declare to the king his dreams; and they came in and stood before the king.
And the king said to them, I have dreamed a dream, and my spirit is troubled to know the dream.
Then the Chaldeans spoke to the king in [xref]a[/xref]Aramaic, [note]1[/note]O king, live forever! Tell the dream to your servants, and we will declare the interpretation.
verse.note: From here through [link]7:28[/link] the text is in Aramaic, not in Hebrew.

verse.text: The king answered and said to the Chaldeans, The command from me is published: If you do not make the dream and its interpretation known to me, you shall be cut into pieces and your houses shall be made a dunghill.
But if you declare the dream and its interpretation, you shall receive gifts and a reward and much honor from me. Therefore declare the dream and its interpretation to me.
They answered a second time and said, Let the king tell his servants the dream, and we will declare the interpretation.
The king answered and said, I know for certain that you are trying to buy time because you have seen that the command from me is published.

But if you do not make the dream known to me, there is but one decree for you; for you have agreed together to speak false and corrupt words before me until the time is changed. Therefore tell me the dream, and I will know that you can declare its interpretation to me.

The Chaldeans answered before the king and said, There is not a man upon the earth who can declare the matter for the king, because no great king or ruler has ever asked any magician, conjurer, or Chaldean for something like this.
And the thing that the king asks is rare, and there is no one else who can declare it before the king except the [xref]a[/xref]gods, whose dwelling is not with flesh.
Because of this the king was angry and very furious, and he gave orders to destroy all the wise men of Babylon.
And the decree went forth that the wise men should be slain; and they sought Daniel and his companions so that they might be slain.
Then Daniel responded in counsel and with discretion to Arioch, the captain of the king's bodyguard, who had gone forth to slay the wise men of Babylon.
He answered and said to Arioch, the king's commander, Why is the decree from before the king so harsh? Then Arioch made the thing known to Daniel.
Daniel then went in and sought from the king that he would give him a time to declare the interpretation to the king.
Then [note]1[/note]Daniel went to his house and made the thing known to [xref]a[/xref]Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, his companions,
verse.note: Nebuchadnezzar's marvelous dream should have impressed him deeply, but because he was blinded by worldly glory and power and did not have a heart for God's interests, he could not understand the dream and eventually forgot it ([link]vv. 1-3[/link]). All the magicians, all the wise men of Babylon, and the Chaldeans were unable to tell him the dream ([link]vv. 4-13[/link]). However, there was a person named Daniel, who did not care for worldly glory and power, who set his heart on the spiritual things regarding God's interests on earth, and who had the right position, the right angle, and the intrinsic capacity within him to understand the dream. He did not have the dream, yet he received the vision from God concerning it ([link]vv. 17-23[/link]), and he interpreted it ([link]vv. 24-45[/link]).

verse.text: That they might request compassions from before the [xref]a[/xref]God of the heavens concerning this mystery so that Daniel and his companions would not be destroyed with the rest of the wise men of Babylon.
verse.xref: Gen. 24:7; 2 Chron. 36:23; Ezra 5:12; Neh. 1:4; Jonah 1:9; Rev. 11:13

verse.text: Then the mystery was revealed to Daniel in a night [xref]a[/xref]vision. Then Daniel blessed the God of the heavens.
Daniel answered and said,[br/]Let the [xref]a[/xref]name of God / Be blessed from eternity to eternity, / For wisdom and might are His.
And it is He who changes the times and seasons; / [xref]a[/xref]He deposes kings and causes kings to ascend. / He gives wisdom to the wise / And knowledge to those who have understanding.
He [xref]a[/xref]reveals the deep things and the hidden things; / He knows what is [i]obscured[/i] in the [xref]b[/xref]darkness, / And the [xref]c[/xref]light dwells with Him.

To You, O God of my fathers, I render thanks and praise, / For You have given me wisdom and might; / And You have now made known to me what we requested of You, / For You have made known the king's matter to us.

Therefore Daniel went in unto Arioch, whom the king had appointed to destroy the wise men of Babylon; he went and said thus to him, Do not destroy the wise men of Babylon; bring me before the king, and I will declare the interpretation to the king.
Then Arioch brought Daniel hurriedly before the king and spoke in this way to him, I have found a man among the captives of Judah who will make the interpretation known to the king.
The king answered and said to Daniel, whose name was Belteshazzar, Are you able to make known to me the dream that I have seen and its interpretation?

Daniel answered before the king and said, As to the mystery which the king has inquired about, no wise men, [i]no[/i] conjurers, magicians, [i]or[/i] diviners, are able to declare [i]it[/i] to the king.

But there is a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]God in the heavens who reveals mysteries, and He has made known to King Nebuchadnezzar what will happen in the last days. This is your dream, even the visions of your head upon your bed.
verse.note: In his interpreting of Nebuchadnezzar's dream, Daniel exalted God ([link]vv. 25-30[/link]). He did not exalt himself.

verse.text: As for you, O king, your thoughts on your bed came upon what would happen after these [i]times,[/i] and He who reveals mysteries has made known to you what will happen.

But as for me, this mystery has not been revealed to me because of some wisdom that is in me more than in any [i]other[/i] living person, but so that the interpretation may be made known to the king and that you may understand the thoughts of your heart.
You, O king, were watching, and there was a single great [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]image. This image, large and its brightness surpassing, stood opposite you; and its appearance was frightful.
verse.note: The contents of Nebuchadnezzar's dream were a great human image and its destiny. The vision of the great image in this chapter is the controlling vision in the book of Daniel. This great image signifies the aggregate of human government throughout human history, from the beginning of human government at Babel (Babylon) in the land of Shinar ([link]Gen. 10:8-10[/link]; [link]11:1-9[/link]), as signified by the head of the image, to the termination of human government in human history in the Roman Empire with the ten kings (see note [link]32[sup]1[/sup][/link], par. 2), as signified by the ten toes ([link]vv. 40-44a[/link]; [link]7:24[/link]; [link]Rev. 13:1[/link]; [link]17:12[/link]). From its beginning to its termination, human government has always done three things: rebel against God, exalt man, and worship idols ([link]Gen. 11:4[/link] and note 2).

verse.text: Concerning this image, its [note]1[/note]head was of fine [xref]a[/xref]gold, its [note]1[/note]breast and its arms of silver, its [note]1[/note]abdomen and its thighs of [xref]b[/xref]bronze,
verse.note: The head of gold ([link]vv. 36-38[/link]), corresponding to the first beast in [link]7:3-4[/link], signifies Nebuchadnezzar, the founder and the king of Babylon. The breast and the arms of silver ([link]v. 39a[/link]), corresponding to the second beast in [link]7:5[/link], signify Medo-Persia, and the abdomen and thighs of bronze ([link]v. 39b[/link]), corresponding to the third beast in [link]7:6[/link], signify Greece, including Macedonia. The legs of iron and the feet partly of iron and partly of clay ([link]v. 33[/link]), corresponding to the fourth beast in [link]7:7-8[/link], signify the Roman Empire with its last ten kings ([link]vv. 40-44a[/link]; [link]7:7-11[/link], [link]19-26[/link]; [link]Rev. 17:7-13[/link]).[br/][br/]According to the human image in this chapter, in the sight of God all human government throughout history is composed of four empires: the Babylonian Empire, the Medo-Persian Empire, the Macedonian-Grecian Empire, and the Roman Empire. The beginning of human government was at Babel (Babylon), which was built by Nimrod ([link]Gen. 10:8-10[/link]), and the ending of human government will be the revived Roman Empire under Antichrist. Although the form and appearance of the Roman Empire have vanished, the culture, spirit, and essence of the Roman Empire continue to exist today (see note [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link]). At the beginning of the great tribulation ([link]Matt. 24:21[/link]) the form and appearance of the Roman Empire will be restored under Antichrist. According to the books of Daniel and Revelation, the last Caesar of the Roman Empire will be Antichrist, who will be supported by ten kings ([link]Rev. 17:10-12[/link] and notes). Thus, the aggregate of human empires that began with Nimrod at Babel will consummate with Antichrist and his ten kings.[br/][br/]If the head of the great human image is Babylon, the entire image must also be Babylon. In the eyes of God, the entire human government from Nimrod to Antichrist is Babylon. Under Antichrist, the last Caesar, the Roman Empire will be both political and religious Babylon ([link]Rev. 17-18[/link]). The empire of Antichrist will be the political and physical Babylon, i.e., "Babylon the Great" ([link]Rev. 18:2[/link]), whereas the Roman Catholic Church, called "MYSTERY, BABYLON THE GREAT" ([link]Rev. 17:5[/link]), will be the religious Babylon. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 1, in Jer. 50[/link].

verse.text: Its [note]1[/note]legs of [xref]a[/xref]iron, its feet partly of iron and partly of clay.
verse.note: The two legs of iron signify the eastern Roman Empire and the western Roman Empire, and the feet and the toes, partly of iron and partly of clay ([link]vv. 41-43[/link]), signify the nations in the period after the fall of Rome and before Christ's second coming. These nations are partly autocratic and partly democratic. The ten toes of the image signify the ten kings of the revived and restored Roman Empire under Antichrist ([link]v. 44a[/link]; [link]7:7[/link], [link]24[/link]; [link]Rev. 17:12[/link]). The periods of history signified by the first three parts of the great human image and the two legs have been fulfilled, but the period signified by the ten toes has not yet been fulfilled. It will be fulfilled at the end of the present age. See note [link]32[sup]1[/sup][/link], par. 2.

verse.text: You were watching until a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]stone was cut out without hands, and it [note]2[/note]struck the image at its feet of iron and clay and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]crushed them.
verse.note: The destiny of the great human image is to be crushed by a stone cut out without hands ([link]vv. 34-35a[/link], [link]44b-45[/link]). This stone is Christ. Through His crucifixion Christ was cut by God by being put to death ([link]Zech. 3:9[/link]; [link]Acts 2:23[/link]), and in His resurrection ([link]Acts 2:24[/link]) He was cut out to be a stone in three aspects: the foundation stone and the cornerstone for the building up of the church ([link]Isa. 28:16[/link]; [link]Matt. 21:42[/link]), the stumbling stone to the unbelieving Jews ([link]Isa. 8:14[/link]; [link]Matt. 21:44a[/link]; [link]Rom. 9:33[/link]), and the crushing stone to destroy the totality of human government ([link]Matt. 21:44b[/link]).[br/][br/]When Christ comes as the crushing stone, He will not come alone; rather, He will come with His overcomers, His bride, His increase, as His army ([link]John 3:29-30[/link]; [link]Rev. 17:14[/link]; [link]19:7-8[/link], [link]11[/link], [link]14[/link]). During the church age, the age of mystery, Christ is building up the church to be His bride ([link]Eph. 5:25-29[/link]). Before He descends to earth, Christ will have a wedding, in which He will marry the overcomers ([link]Rev. 19:7-9[/link]), those who have been fighting the battle against God's enemy for years and who have already overcome the evil one (cf. [link]Rev. 12:11[/link]). After His wedding, He as the Husband will come with His newlywed bride to destroy Antichrist, who with his army will fight against God directly ([link]Rev. 17:14[/link]; [link]19:19[/link]).

At His appearing as the God-cut stone, Christ with His overcomers — the corporate Christ — will strike the ten kings with Antichrist ([link]Rev. 19:11-21[/link]), thereby crushing the great image from the toes to the head ([link]v. 35[/link]). This will be Christ's universal judgment on the aggregate of human government from Antichrist back to Nimrod, thus ending the age of man's government on earth in the old creation and initiating the age of God's dominion over the entire earth in the millennium and in the new heaven and new earth for eternity.

verse.text: Then the iron, the clay, the bronze, the silver, and the gold were crushed [note]1[/note]all at once, and they became like [xref]a[/xref]chaff from the summer threshing floors; and the wind carried them away so that [note]2[/note]no trace of them was found. And the stone that struck the image became a great [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]mountain and filled the [xref]c[/xref]whole earth.
verse.note: This signifies the complete destruction of all human government from Nimrod to Antichrist.
Or, no place was found for them.

The great mountain here signifies the eternal kingdom of God, which will fill the whole earth forever ([link]v. 44[/link]; [link]7:13-14[/link]). After coming to crush the aggregate of human government, the corporate Christ — Christ with His overcoming bride — will become a great mountain to fill the whole earth, making the whole earth God's kingdom. Thus the great human image will be replaced with the eternal kingdom of God on earth ([link]Rev. 11:15-17[/link]).[br/][br/]The increase of the stone into a great mountain signifies the increase of Christ (cf. [link]John 3:29-30[/link]). The church is Christ's increase in life, but the eternal kingdom of God is Christ's increase in administration ([link]Mark 4:26-29[/link]). Hence, Christ is not only the church but also the kingdom of God ([link]1 Cor. 12:12[/link]; [link]Luke 17:21[/link]). As the stone, Christ is the centrality of God's move, and as the mountain, He is the universality. Hence, He is the all-inclusive One, the One who fills all in all ([link]Eph. 1:23[/link]).

verse.text: This is the dream; and we will tell its interpretation before the king.
You, O king, are [xref]a[/xref]king of kings, to whom the [xref]b[/xref]God of the heavens has given kingship, power, and strength and glory.

And wherever the children of men, the [xref]a[/xref]beasts of the field, or the birds of the sky dwell, He has given [i]them[/i] into your hand and has made you ruler over all of them. You are the [xref]b[/xref]head of gold.
And after you [xref]a[/xref]another kingdom will arise, inferior to you; and [i]there will be[/i] another kingdom, a [xref]b[/xref]third one, of bronze, which will rule over all the earth.
And there will be a [xref]a[/xref]fourth kingdom as strong as iron, inasmuch as iron crushes and shatters everything; and like iron that smashes all these, it will crush and smash.

And in that you saw the [xref]a[/xref]feet and the toes, partly of potter's clay and partly of iron, the kingdom will be a [note]1[/note]confused mass; but there will be some of the [note]2[/note]firmness of iron in it, for you saw the iron mixed with the [note]3[/note]earthy clay.
verse.note: Lit., divided.
Denoting standing strength.
Emphasizing the notion of clay in contrast to the notion of iron.

verse.text: And [i]as[/i] the toes of the feet were partly of iron and partly of clay, [i]so[/i] some of the kingdom will be strong and part of it will be fragile.
And in that you saw the iron mixed with the earthy clay, they will be mixed together through the seed of men, but they will not cleave to one another, even as iron does not mix with clay.

And in the days of those kings the [xref]a[/xref]God of the heavens will raise up a [xref]b[/xref]kingdom which will [xref]c[/xref]never be destroyed, and its reign will not be left to another people; it will crush and put an end to all these kingdoms; and it will stand forever.

Inasmuch as you saw that out of the mountain a [xref]a[/xref]stone was cut without hands and that it crushed the iron, the bronze, the clay, the silver, and the gold, the great God has made known to the king what will happen afterward; and the dream is certain, and its interpretation trustworthy.
Then King Nebuchadnezzar [xref]a[/xref]fell on his face and worshipped Daniel and commanded that they offer an oblation and incense to him.
The king answered Daniel and said, It is certain that your God is the God of gods and the Lord of kings and a [xref]a[/xref]Revealer of mysteries, for you have been able to reveal this mystery.

Then the king made Daniel great and gave many great gifts to him; and he made him [xref]a[/xref]ruler over the whole province of Babylon and [xref]b[/xref]chief of the prefects over all the wise men of Babylon.
And Daniel requested of the king, and he appointed [xref]a[/xref]Shadrach, Meshach, and Abed-nego over the administration of the province of Babylon; but Daniel was at the king's court.
Nebuchadnezzar the king made an [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]image of gold, its height sixty cubits [i]and[/i] its width six cubits; he set it up in the plain of Dura in the province of Babylon.
verse.note: Nebuchadnezzar might have been influenced to make such an image by the interpretation of his dream in [link]2:37-38[/link].

verse.text: Then Nebuchadnezzar the king sent word to assemble the satraps, the prefects and the governors, the chief judges, the treasury officials, the law officials, the judges, and all the rulers of the provinces to come to the dedication of the image that Nebuchadnezzar the king had set up.

Then the satraps, the prefects and the governors, the chief judges, the treasury officials, the law officials, the judges, and all the [note]1[/note]rulers of the provinces assembled themselves for the dedication of the image that Nebuchadnezzar the king had set up; and they stood before the image that Nebuchadnezzar had set up.
verse.note: Since Daniel is not mentioned in this chapter, it is likely that he stayed away from the dedication of the image in order to pray for God's victory in the situation.

verse.text: Then a herald proclaimed loudly, To you it is commanded, O peoples, [xref]a[/xref]nations, and languages,

At the time that you hear the sound of the horn, flute, lyre, trigon, psaltery, bagpipe, and all kinds of music, you shall fall down and [xref]a[/xref]worship the golden image that Nebuchadnezzar the king has set up;
And whoever does not fall down and worship shall be thrown into the midst of a blazing furnace of [xref]a[/xref]fire in that very hour.

Therefore at that time, when all the peoples heard the sound of the horn, flute, lyre, trigon, psaltery, [note]1[/note]bagpipe, and all kinds of music, all the peoples, nations, and languages fell down and worshipped the golden image that Nebuchadnezzar the king had set up.
verse.note: Some MSS omit, bagpipe.

verse.text: Because of this at that time certain Chaldeans drew near and [xref]a[/xref]accused the Jews.
They responded and said to Nebuchadnezzar the king, O king, live forever!
You, O king, have made a decree that every man who hears the sound of the horn, flute, lyre, trigon, psaltery, bagpipe, and all kinds of music shall fall down and worship the golden image;
And whoever does not fall down and worship shall be thrown into the midst of a blazing furnace of fire.

There are certain Jews, whom you have appointed over the administration of the province of Babylon — [xref]a[/xref]Shadrach, Meshach, and Abed-nego — these men have not respected you, O king; they do not serve your gods nor worship the golden image that you have set up.
Then Nebuchadnezzar in rage and fury commanded [i]men[/i] to bring Shadrach, Meshach, and Abed-nego; then they brought these men before the king.
Nebuchadnezzar responded and said to them, Do you, Shadrach, Meshach, and Abed-nego, purposely not serve my [xref]a[/xref]gods nor [xref]b[/xref]worship the golden image that I have set up?

Now then, if, at the time when you hear the sound of the horn, flute, lyre, trigon, psaltery, bagpipe, and all kinds of music, you are ready to fall down and worship the image that I have made, [i]very well;[/i] but if you do not worship, you will be thrown into the midst of a blazing furnace of fire in that very hour; and who is that god who will [xref]a[/xref]deliver you out of my hands?
Shadrach, Meshach, and Abed-nego answered and said to the king, O Nebuchadnezzar, there is no need for us to give you an answer in this matter.
If it be [i]so,[/i] our God whom we serve is able to [xref]a[/xref]deliver us from the blazing furnace of fire, and He will deliver [i]us[/i] out of your hand, O king.
But if [i]He does[/i] not, let it be known to you, O king, that we will not serve your gods nor worship the golden image that you have set up.

Then Nebuchadnezzar was filled with fury and the countenance of his face was changed toward Shadrach, Meshach, and Abed-nego. He responded and commanded that the furnace be made seven times hotter than it was usually heated.
And he commanded certain mighty men who were in his army to bind Shadrach, Meshach, and Abed-nego, and throw them into the blazing furnace of fire.
Then these men were bound in their shirts, tunics, and mantles, and [i]other[/i] clothing, and thrown into the midst of the blazing furnace of fire.
For this reason, because the king's word was so harsh and the furnace had been heated to an extreme, the flame of the fire slew those men who carried up Shadrach, Meshach, and Abed-nego.
And these three men, Shadrach, Meshach, and Abed-nego, fell into the midst of the blazing furnace of fire bound up.

Then Nebuchadnezzar the king was astonished and stood up in haste; he responded and said to his counselors, Did we not throw three men into the midst of the fire bound up? They answered and said to the king, Certainly, O king.

He answered and said, Look, I see four men loose, [xref]a[/xref]walking in the midst of the fire; and they are not harmed. And the appearance of the [note]1[/note]fourth is like a [xref]b[/xref]son of the gods.
verse.note: This fourth one was the excellent Christ as the Son of Man, who had come to be with His three suffering, persecuted overcomers and to make the fire a pleasant place in which to walk about. The three overcomers did not need to ask God to deliver them from the furnace (cf. [link]v. 17[/link]). Christ as the Son of Man — the One who is qualified and capable of sympathizing with God's people in everything ([link]Heb. 4:15[/link]) — came to be their Companion and take care of them in their suffering, by His presence making their place of suffering a pleasant situation.

verse.text: Then Nebuchadnezzar came near to the door of the blazing furnace of fire. He responded and said, Shadrach, Meshach, and Abed-nego, [xref]a[/xref]servants of God the [xref]b[/xref]Most High, come out and come here. Then Shadrach, Meshach, and Abed-nego came out of the midst of the fire.

And the satraps, prefects, and governors, and the king's counselors, being gathered together, saw concerning these men that the fire had [xref]a[/xref]no effect on their bodies and [i]that[/i] the hair of their heads was not singed, nor had their clothes been affected, nor had the smell of fire come upon them.

Nebuchadnezzar responded and said, Blessed be the God of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abed-nego, who has sent His [xref]a[/xref]angel and delivered His servants who trusted in Him and [note]1[/note]changed the king's word and yielded their [xref]b[/xref]bodies that they might not serve nor worship any god except their own God.
verse.note: The three young overcomers did not simply frustrate the king's word — they changed it in nature and were not afraid to yield their bodies to be killed. Thus, they gained the victory over the seduction of idol worship. Because of their victory God could boast to Satan that even in his territory He had a people who worshipped Him.

verse.text: Therefore I make a decree that any people, nation, or language that speaks something offensive against the God of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abed-nego shall be cut into pieces and their houses shall be made a dunghill, because there is no other god who is able to deliver in this way.
Then the king caused Shadrach, Meshach, and Abed-nego to prosper in the province of Babylon.
Nebuchadnezzar the king to all the peoples, nations, and languages that dwell in the whole earth: May your [xref]a[/xref]peace abound!
It pleases me to declare the signs and wonders that God the Most High has done for me.
How great are His signs, / And how mighty are His wonders! / His kingdom is an [xref]a[/xref]eternal kingdom, / And His dominion is from generation to generation.
I, Nebuchadnezzar, was at ease in my house and was flourishing in my palace.
I saw a dream and it frightened me, and the imaginings upon my bed and the [xref]a[/xref]visions of my head alarmed me.
Therefore I made the decree to bring before me all the wise men of Babylon that they might make the interpretation of the dream known to me.
Then the magicians, conjurers, Chaldeans, and diviners came in, and I told the dream to them; but they [xref]a[/xref]could not make its interpretation known to me.

But at last there came in before me Daniel, whose name is [xref]a[/xref]Belteshazzar, according to the name of my god, and in whom is a [xref]b[/xref]spirit of the holy gods; and I told the dream to him, [i]saying,[/i]

O Belteshazzar, chief of the magicians, because I know that a spirit of the holy gods is in you and no mystery troubles you, [i]here are[/i] the visions of my dream that I have seen; now tell [i]me[/i] its interpretation.
Now [i]these were[/i] the visions of my head upon my bed: I was watching and there was a [xref]a[/xref]tree in the midst of the earth, and its height was great.
The tree grew great and became strong, / And its height reached to heaven, / And the sight of it to the end of all the earth.

Its foliage was beautiful and its fruit abundant, / And in it was food for all. / The beasts of the field found shade under it, / And the birds of the sky dwelt in its branches; / And all flesh fed from it.
I was watching in the visions of my head upon my bed, and there was a [xref]a[/xref]watcher, indeed, a [xref]b[/xref]holy one, coming down from heaven.
verse.xref: Deut. 33:2; Psa. 89:5, 7; Dan. 8:13; cf. Zech. 14:5; Jude 14

verse.text: He cried out loudly and spoke in this way, / [xref]a[/xref]Cut down the tree and cut off its branches; / Strip off its foliage and scatter its fruit; / Let the beasts flee from under it, / And the birds from its branches.

Yet leave its stump of roots / In the earth, / But with an iron and bronze band [i]around it,[/i] / In the tender grass of the field; / And let him be wet with the dew of heaven, / And let his portion be with the beasts in the grass of the earth;
Let his mind be changed from that of a man's, / And let a beast's mind be given to him; / And let seven [xref]a[/xref]periods of time pass over him.

This matter is by the decree of the watchers, and the decision is a command of the holy ones, to the intent that the living may know that the [note]1[/note]Most High is the [xref]a[/xref]Ruler over the kingdom of men and [xref]b[/xref]gives it to whomever He wills and sets up over it the lowliest of men.
verse.note: God taught Nebuchadnezzar to know that he was nothing and that the mighty God, who gives the kingdom of men to whomever He wills, is everything.

verse.text: This dream I, King Nebuchadnezzar, have seen. Now you, Belteshazzar, tell [i]me[/i] the interpretation, inasmuch as all the wise men of my kingdom are [xref]a[/xref]not able to make the interpretation known to me; but you are able, for a spirit of the holy gods is in you.

Then Daniel, whose name is Belteshazzar, was appalled for a while as his thoughts alarmed him. The king responded and said, Belteshazzar, do not let the dream or its interpretation alarm you. Belteshazzar answered and said, My lord, may the dream be for those who hate you, and its interpretation for your enemies!
The tree that you saw, which grew great and became strong, and whose height reached to heaven and the sight of it to all the earth,
And whose foliage was beautiful and its fruit abundant, and in which was food for all, [i]and[/i] under which the beasts of the field dwelt, and in whose branches the birds of the sky lodged —
It is you, O king, who have grown great and become strong, for your greatness has grown and reaches to heaven, and your dominion to the end of the earth.

And in that the king saw a watcher, indeed, a holy one, coming down from heaven and saying, Cut down the tree and destroy it; yet leave its stump of roots in the earth, but with an iron and bronze band [i]around it,[/i] in the tender grass of the field; and let him be wet with the dew of heaven, and let his portion be with the beasts of the field until seven periods of time pass over him;
This is the interpretation, O king, and this is the decree of the Most High, which has come upon my lord the king:

[xref]a[/xref]You shall be driven out from among mankind, and with the beasts of the field shall your dwelling place be; and you shall be made to eat grass as bulls [i]do[/i] and shall be wet with the dew of heaven; and seven periods of time will pass over you, until you come to know that the Most High is the Ruler over the kingdom of men and gives it to whomever He wills.
And in that it was commanded that the stump of roots of the tree be left, your kingdom will be assured to you after you have come to know that the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]heavens do rule.
verse.note: The book of Daniel covers three crucial matters: God's heavenly rule, the preeminence of Christ, and the destiny apportioned by God for His people. In His economy God administrates the universe, including all the kings and kingdoms on the earth, in order to fulfill His purpose, which is that Christ should be preeminent in all things ([link]Col. 1:18[/link]). For Christ to be preeminent, God needs a chosen people to coordinate and cooperate with Him. Under the rule of the heavens, everything is working together for the good of God's elect for the purpose of making Christ preeminent ([link]Rom. 8:28-29[/link]).

verse.text: Therefore, O king, let my counsel be acceptable to you: Break off your sins by doing righteousness, and your iniquities by showing mercy to the poor; perhaps there may be a prolonging of your prosperity.
All this came upon Nebuchadnezzar the king.
At the end of [note]1[/note]twelve months he was walking upon [i]the roof of[/i] the royal palace of Babylon.
verse.note: God gave Nebuchadnezzar twelve months to repent. However, Nebuchadnezzar was void of the capacity to know God inwardly, and nothing within him was touched. Hence, there was no repentance and no change; rather, Nebuchadnezzar was filled with pride ([link]vv. 30[/link], [link]37[/link]; [link]5:20[/link]) and thus came under God's judgment ([link]Prov. 16:18[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 5:5[/link]).

verse.text: The king responded and said, Is this not [xref]a[/xref]Babylon the great, which I have built up as a royal house by the might of my power and for the [xref]b[/xref]glory of my majesty?
While the word was still in the king's mouth, a voice came down from heaven: To you it is spoken, King Nebuchadnezzar: The kingdom has passed on from you;

[xref]a[/xref]And from among mankind you shall be driven out, and with the [note]1[/note]beasts of the field shall your dwelling place be; you shall be made to eat grass as bulls [i]do;[/i] and [note]2[/note]seven periods of time will pass over you, until you come to know that the Most High is the Ruler over the kingdom of men and gives it to whomever He wills.
verse.note: According to his nature and his being, Nebuchadnezzar was not a man but a beast. For this reason, his heart was changed from that of a man's, and a beast's heart was given to him ([link]v. 16[/link]). God also took away his human reasoning (cf. [link]v. 34[/link]).
The expression [i]seven periods of time[/i] may refer to seven weeks, to forty-nine days.

verse.text: In that very hour the word concerning Nebuchadnezzar was fulfilled; and from among mankind he was driven out, and he began to eat grass as bulls [i]do,[/i] and his body was wet with the dew of heaven, until his hair had grown like eagles' [i]feathers[/i] and his nails like birds' [i]claws.[/i]

And at the end of [i]those[/i] days I, Nebuchadnezzar, lifted up my eyes to heaven, and [note]1[/note]reason returned to me; and I blessed the Most High, and I praised and honored the [xref]a[/xref]ever-living One;[br/]For [xref]b[/xref]His dominion is an eternal dominion, / And His kingdom is from generation to generation;
verse.note: Lit., my reason. So also in [link]v. 36[/link]. Because beasts walk on four legs, they look down, but humans walk on two feet and look up. Nebuchadnezzar's reasoning came back as soon as he looked upward toward the heavens. Because he had changed, his reasoning returned.

verse.text: And all the inhabitants of earth are considered as [xref]a[/xref]nothing, / But He [xref]b[/xref]does according to His will in the army of heaven / And [i]among[/i] the inhabitants of the earth; / And there is no one who can resist His hand / Or say to Him, [xref]c[/xref]What are You doing?

At that time reason returned to me; and for the glory of my kingdom, my majesty and splendor returned to me; and my counselors and my lords sought me out, and I was established in my kingdom, and surpassing greatness was added to me.
Now I, Nebuchadnezzar, praise and exalt and honor the King of the heavens, because all His works are truth and His ways justice, and because He is able to abase those who walk in [xref]a[/xref]pride.
[note]1[/note]Belshazzar the king [note]2[/note]made a great feast for a thousand of his lords; and he [note]2[/note]drank wine before the thousand.
verse.note: The son of Nabonidus and ruler of Babylon (556-539 B.C.) under him.
This was Belshazzar's debauchery before God.

verse.text: Belshazzar, [note]1[/note]under the influence of the wine, commanded men to bring the gold and silver [xref]a[/xref]vessels that Nebuchadnezzar his forefather had taken out of the temple which was in Jerusalem, that the king and his lords, his wives, and his concubines might drink from them.
verse.note: Or, when he tasted the wine.

verse.text: Then they brought the golden vessels that had been taken out of the temple of the house of God, which was in Jerusalem; and the king and his lords, his wives, and his concubines drank from them.
They drank wine and praised the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]gods of gold and of silver, of bronze, iron, wood, and stone.
verse.note: Belshazzar's taking the vessels that were for God's worship in His holy temple at Jerusalem and using them in worshipping idols was an insult to God's holiness.

verse.text: At that [xref]a[/xref]moment the fingers of a man's hand came forth and wrote opposite the lampstand upon the plaster of the wall of the king's palace. And the king saw [i]that[/i] part of the hand that wrote.
Then the king's countenance changed and his thoughts alarmed him; and the joints of his hips loosened and his knees began to knock together.

The king cried loudly to bring the conjurers, the Chaldeans, and the diviners. The king responded and said to the wise men of Babylon, Any man who reads this writing and declares its interpretation to me shall be clothed in purple and [i]shall have[/i] a chain of gold around his neck and shall rule as the [xref]a[/xref]third [i]ruler[/i] in the kingdom.
Then all the king's wise men came, but they could not read the writing [xref]a[/xref]nor make its interpretation known to the king.
Then King Belshazzar was greatly alarmed; his countenance was [i]further[/i] changed, and his lords were perplexed.

The queen mother, because of the words of the king and his lords, came to the banquet house. The queen mother responded and said, O king, live forever! Do not let your thoughts alarm you, nor let your countenance change.

There is a man in your kingdom in whom is a [xref]a[/xref]spirit of the holy gods; and in the days of your forefather light and insight and wisdom like the wisdom of the gods were found in him. And King Nebuchadnezzar your forefather — your forefather, O king — made him chief of the magicians, conjurers, Chaldeans, [i]and[/i] diviners,

Because an [xref]a[/xref]excellent spirit and knowledge and insight, [i]and[/i] the interpretation of dreams, the declaring of riddles, and the resolving of problems were found in this Daniel, whom the king named [xref]b[/xref]Belteshazzar. Let Daniel now be called, and he will declare the interpretation.
Then Daniel was brought before the king. The king responded and said to Daniel, Are you Daniel, one of the captives of Judah, whom my forefather the king brought from Judah?
Now I have heard about you that a spirit of the gods is in you and [i]that[/i] light and insight and surpassing wisdom are found in you.
And now the wise men, the conjurers, have been brought in before me that they might read this writing and make its interpretation known to me, but they cannot declare the interpretation of the thing.

But I have heard about you that you can give interpretations and resolve problems. If you can now read the writing and make its interpretation known to me, you shall be clothed in purple and [i]shall have[/i] a chain of gold around your neck and shall rule as the third [i]ruler[/i] in the kingdom.

Then Daniel answered and said before the king, Let your [xref]a[/xref]gifts remain with you, or give your rewards to another; nevertheless I will read the writing for the king and make the interpretation known to him.
Regarding [note]1[/note]you, O king, God the Most High [xref]a[/xref]gave to Nebuchadnezzar your forefather kingship, greatness, glory, and majesty;
verse.note: Before reading the writing and interpreting it, Daniel reminded Belshazzar of the experience of Nebuchadnezzar his forefather in [link]ch. 4[/link] ([link chapter="4"]vv. 18-37[/link]). Daniel regarded what happened to Nebuchadnezzar as a lesson not only for Nebuchadnezzar but also for all his descendants. Belshazzar should have learned the lesson from Nebuchadnezzar's experience; however, he did not learn the lesson and suffered as a result.

verse.text: And because of the greatness which He gave to him, all peoples, nations, and languages trembled and feared before him; whomever he wished he slew, and whomever he wished he kept alive, and whomever he wished he raised up, and whomever he wished he brought down.

But when his heart was [xref]a[/xref]lifted up and his spirit became so arrogant that he conducted himself in pride, he was deposed from his royal throne, and [i]his[/i] glory was taken away from him.

[xref]a[/xref]And he was driven from the sons of men, and his heart was made like that of the beasts, and his dwelling place was with the wild donkeys; [i]men[/i] fed him with grass as [i]they do[/i] bulls, and his body was wet with the dew of heaven, until he came to know that God the Most High is the Ruler over the kingdom of men and sets over it whomever He wills.
And you his descendant, Belshazzar, have [xref]a[/xref]not humbled your heart, though you knew all this;

But you have exalted yourself against the Lord of the heavens; and they have brought the [xref]a[/xref]vessels of His house before you, and you and your lords, your wives, and your concubines have drunk wine from them; and you have praised the [xref]b[/xref]gods of silver and of gold, of bronze, iron, wood, and stone, which do not see nor hear nor know. But the God in whose hand is your [xref]c[/xref]breath and to whom all your ways [i]belong,[/i] you have not honored.
Then [i]that[/i] part of the hand was sent from before Him, and this writing was inscribed.
And this is the writing that was inscribed: [note]1[/note]MENE, MENE, TEKEL, UPHARSIN.
verse.note: Meaning at the same time both [i]mina, mina, shekel, and half-shekels[/i] (monetary units) and [i]numbered, numbered, weighed, and divided;[/i] the last word of the inscription also closely resembles the Aramaic name for the Persians, [i]paras.[/i]

verse.text: This is the interpretation of the matter: MENE — God has numbered your kingdom and brought it to an end;
TEKEL — You have been weighed in the [xref]a[/xref]scales and found to be lacking.
PERES — Your kingdom has been divided and given to the [xref]a[/xref]Medes and Persians.

Then Belshazzar commanded; and they clothed Daniel in purple and [i]put[/i] a chain of gold around his neck, and they made the proclamation concerning him that he should rule as the third [i]ruler[/i] in the kingdom.
In that very night Belshazzar the Chaldean king was [note]1[/note]slain.
verse.note: This ended the Babylonian Empire. God used the Babylonian Empire for the purpose of carrying His corrupted and defeated elect into captivity. Near the end of the seventy years of their captivity, God caused the Medes and the Persians to become one for the purpose of ending the Babylonian Empire and releasing His people from their captivity in Babylon ([link]Ezra 1:1-4[/link]). This is an illustration of how all kings and kingdoms are under God's administration. See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

verse.text: And Darius the Mede received the kingdom at about the age of sixty-two.
It pleased Darius to set up over the kingdom a hundred and twenty satraps, who would be throughout the whole [xref]a[/xref]kingdom;
And over them, three chief ministers — of whom Daniel was one — so that these satraps might give account to them and the king might not suffer loss.
Then this Daniel distinguished himself among the chief ministers and satraps because in him there was an [xref]a[/xref]excellent spirit, and the king considered setting him over the whole kingdom.

Then the chief ministers and satraps sought to find a ground for accusation against Daniel from the perspective of the kingdom, but they could find no ground for accusation or fault, inasmuch as he was faithful, and no negligence or fault was found related to him.
Then these men said, We will not find any ground for accusation against this Daniel unless we find [i]something[/i] related to him due to the law of his God.
Then these chief ministers and satraps came to prevail upon the king and said thus to him, King Darius, live forever!

All the chief ministers of the kingdom, the prefects and the satraps, the counselors and the governors, have taken counsel together that the king should establish a statute and make firm an edict that anyone who makes a [note]1[/note]petition within the [i]next[/i] thirty days to any god or man besides you, O king, shall be cast into the lions' den.
verse.note: The center of this chapter is man's prayer for the carrying out of God's economy. Through His faithful channels of prayer God carries out His economy with His elect for Christ's coming. God desires to carry out His economy, but man is needed to pray for His economy on earth. Satan's strategy is to frustrate the prayer that is for God's move. The intention of the chief ministers and satraps was to destroy Daniel, but the intention of Satan, who was behind them, was to cut off the channel of prayer that God was using for the carrying out of His economy.

verse.text: Now, O king, establish the edict and sign the writing, so that it is not changed, according to the law of the Medes and Persians, which cannot pass away.
Therefore King Darius signed the writing, that is, the edict.

Now when [note]1[/note]Daniel came to know that the writing had been signed, he went to his house (in his upper room he had windows open [note]2[/note]toward [xref]a[/xref]Jerusalem) and [xref]b[/xref]three times daily he knelt on his knees and prayed and gave thanks before his God, because he had [i]always[/i] done so previously.
verse.note: Daniel had read Jeremiah's prophecy that the children of Israel would serve the king of Babylon for seventy years ([link]9:2b[/link]; [link]Jer. 25:11[/link]). Standing on this word, he must have prayed many times for the fulfillment of this prophecy and for the return of the captives. He would not let anything stop or frustrate his prayer. He knew that his prayer was for the carrying out of God's economy concerning His elect. Therefore, his prayer was a serious matter.
See note [link]48[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Kings 8[/link].

verse.text: Then these men assembled and found Daniel making petition and supplication before his God.

Then they came near and spoke before the king concerning the king's edict: Did you not sign an edict that anyone who petitions, within the [i]next[/i] thirty days, any god or man besides you, O king, shall be cast into the lions' den? The king answered and said, The thing is certain, according to the law of the Medes and Persians, which cannot pass away.
Then they answered and said before the king, Daniel, one of the captives from Judah, has not respected you, O king, or the edict that you have signed, but three times daily makes his petition.
Then the king, when he heard the thing, was very displeased with himself and set his heart on delivering Daniel; and until the sun set, he made efforts to deliver him.
Then these men came to prevail upon the king and said to the king, Know, O king, that it is the law of the Medes and Persians that no edict or statute which the king establishes can be changed.

Then the king commanded, and they brought Daniel and threw [i]him[/i] into the lions' den. The king responded and said to Daniel, Your God, whom you [xref]a[/xref]serve continually, He will deliver you.

And a stone was brought and set over the mouth of the den. And the king [xref]a[/xref]sealed it with his signet ring and with the signet rings of his lords that nothing might be changed regarding Daniel.
Then the king went to his palace and spent the night fasting; and no entertainment was brought before him, and his sleep fled from him.
Then the king arose at dawn at the first light, and went in haste to the lions' den.

And when he had come near the den, he shouted to Daniel with a sad voice; the king responded and said to Daniel, O Daniel, servant of the [xref]a[/xref]living God, has your God, whom you serve continually, been able to [xref]b[/xref]deliver you from the lions?
Then Daniel said to the king, O king, live forever!

My God has sent His [xref]a[/xref]angel and has shut the [xref]b[/xref]lions' mouth, and they have not hurt me, inasmuch as before Him innocence was found in me; and also before you, O king, I have done no harm.

Then the king was very pleased concerning him, and he commanded that they take Daniel up out of the den. So Daniel was taken up out of the den, and he was found completely unhurt, because he had trusted in his God.

Then the king commanded, and they brought those men who had accused Daniel and threw [i]them[/i] into the lions' den, them, their children, and their wives; and they had not reached the bottom of the den before the lions overpowered them and crushed all their bones.
[note]1[/note]Then Darius the king wrote to all the peoples, nations, and languages that dwell in the whole land: May your [xref]a[/xref]peace abound!
verse.note: [link]Verses 25-28[/link] reveal God's victory over Satan in the worship of God on earth, even in a Gentile kingdom, through the overcomers in the captivity of His defeated elect. Daniel's victory over the subtlety that prohibited the faithfulness of the overcomers in the worship of God was the last step of the victory over Satan's devices. Without these overcomers God would have been fully defeated by Satan, having nothing on earth for Himself. God had four young overcomers living in the palace day by day who were absolutely one with Him. This was a shame to Satan and a boast to God.

verse.text: I make a decree that in all the dominion of my kingdom men tremble and fear before the God of Daniel;[br/]For He is the living God / And enduring forever; / And His [xref]a[/xref]kingdom is one which will not be destroyed, / And His dominion will be unto the end.
He delivers and rescues, / And He does signs and wonders / In heaven and on earth; / [i]It is He[/i] who has delivered Daniel from the power of the lions.
And this Daniel prospered in the reign of Darius and in the reign of [xref]a[/xref]Cyrus the Persian.

In the [note]1[/note]first year of Belshazzar the king of Babylon Daniel saw a dream and [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]visions of his head upon his bed. Then he wrote down the dream; he related the sum of the matters.
verse.note: This was about 556 B.C., twenty years before the return of the children of Israel from captivity in about 536 B.C.

The section of this book from [link]1:3-6:28[/link] speaks of the victory, in their captivity, of God's degraded elect over Satan's further devices. The section from [link]7:1-12:13[/link] records the visions of the overcoming Daniel. Daniel's faithfulness and victory gave him the position and the right angle to receive the visions from God.

verse.text: Daniel responded and said, I was watching in my vision by night, and there were the [note]1[/note]four [xref]a[/xref]winds of heaven, stirring up the [note]2[/note]Great Sea.
verse.note: The four winds of heaven signify moves of heaven from four directions, the stirring up of the Great Sea signifies the stirring up of the political situation around the Mediterranean Sea, and the four beasts that came up from the sea signify four great, fierce, cruel, and inhuman kings with their empires ([link]v. 17[/link]). That the four winds are "of heaven" does not mean that heaven is the source of the four beasts but that heaven arranged the situation that produced them.

I.e., the Mediterranean Sea. The sea signifies the Gentile nations ([link]vv. 3[/link], [link]17[/link]; [link]Rev. 17:15[/link]). God's economy in His creation was to make the Mediterranean area the center of culture up to the time of Columbus. Human culture has become a great sea full of winds and storms.

verse.text: And four great [note]1[/note]beasts [xref]a[/xref]came up from the sea, each different from the other.
verse.note: In Nebuchadnezzar's dream ([link]2:31-45[/link]) human government on the earth was signified by a great human image full of glory and splendor. In the vision of God's prophet Daniel in this chapter, the heads of human government on the earth, and the governments themselves, are signified by wild beasts.

verse.text: The [note]1[/note]first was like a [xref]a[/xref]lion and had the wings of an [xref]b[/xref]eagle. I watched until its wings were plucked and it was lifted up from the earth and made to stand on two feet like a man; and a man's heart was given to it.
verse.note: The first beast corresponds to the head of gold of the great human image in [link]2:32a[/link], [link]36-38[/link], signifying Babylon with its king, Nebuchadnezzar. Its being like a lion, the king of the beasts, signifies that it was the most fierce and cruel, and its having the wings of an eagle, the king of the fowls, signifies that it was in the air, which belongs to Satan, the ruler of the air ([link]Eph. 2:2[/link]), and that its move was swift. The plucking of its wings signifies that its moving power was taken away and that it became like a beast in the field, as mentioned in [link]4:23-25a[/link], [link]33[/link]. This beast became like a man standing on the earth with a man's heart, as indicated in [link]4:25b[/link], [link]32b[/link], [link]34a[/link].

verse.text: And there was [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]another beast, a second one, resembling a [xref]b[/xref]bear. And it was raised up on one side, and three ribs were in its mouth between its teeth; and they said thus to it, Arise, devour much flesh.
verse.note: The second beast corresponds to the breast and arms of silver of the great human image in [link]2:32b[/link], [link]39a[/link], signifying Medo-Persia. Its resembling a bear signifies that it was not as strong and swift as the lion but that it was still fierce and cruel. Its being raised up on one side signifies that Media and Persia became one dominion. That three ribs were in its mouth between its teeth signifies that three kingdoms, Babylon, Asia Minor, and Egypt, were devoured by it. Its being commanded to arise and devour much flesh signifies that it would devour more nations.

verse.text: After this I watched and there was [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]another [i]beast,[/i] like a [xref]b[/xref]leopard; and it had four wings of a bird on its back; and the beast had [xref]c[/xref]four heads, and dominion was given to it.
verse.note: The third beast corresponds to the abdomen and thighs of bronze of the great human image in [link]2:32c[/link], [link]39b[/link], signifying Greece with its king, Alexander the Great. Its being like a leopard signifies that it was fierce, cruel, and swift ([link]Hab. 1:8a[/link]). That it had four wings of a bird on its back signifies that it was swift by means of its four generals. The beast had four heads, signifying that the four wings for swiftness became four heads, four generals who became the heads of four kingdoms. After the death of Alexander the Great, his four generals divided his empire into four kingdoms (see note [link]8[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 8[/link]). That the beast was given dominion signifies that it was given authority to rule over the nations.

verse.text: After this I watched in the night visions, and there was a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fourth beast, dreadful and frightful and exceedingly strong; and it had large iron teeth; it devoured and crushed and trampled down the remainder with its feet; and it was different from all the beasts that were before it; and it had [xref]b[/xref]ten horns.
verse.note: The fourth beast corresponds to the legs of iron and the feet and the toes, partly of iron and partly of clay, of the great human image in [link]2:33[/link], [link]40-43[/link], signifying the Roman Empire, and specifically Antichrist, the last Caesar of the Roman Empire ([link]Rev. 17:7-11[/link]). This is the beast revealed in [link]Rev. 13:1-2[/link]. The fourth beast was dreadful and frightful and exceedingly strong, as signified by iron. That it had large iron teeth and claws of bronze, and that it devoured, crushed, and trampled down the remainder ([link]vv. 19[/link], [link]23[/link]) signify that it had great power to devour and crush nations. The beast having ten horns signifies that it had ten kings ([link]v. 24[/link]; [link]Rev. 17:12-13[/link]), which are the ten toes of the great human image in [link]ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: I was considering the horns; then there was another horn, a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]small one, which came up among them; and [xref]b[/xref]three of the first horns were uprooted from before it. And there were [note]2[/note]eyes like the eyes of a man in this horn and a [note]2[/note]mouth speaking [xref]c[/xref]great things.
verse.note: A small horn coming up among the ten horns and three of the ten horns being uprooted before it ([link]vv. 20b[/link], [link]24[/link]) signifies that Antichrist will come up among the ten kings, and before him three of them will be destroyed. In this way Antichrist will become the strongest horn.

The small horn having eyes like the eyes of a man and a mouth speaking great things ([link]vv. 20c[/link], [link]25a[/link]) signifies that Antichrist will have sharp insight to perceive things and a mouth to speak blasphemous words against God ([link]Rev. 13:5a[/link], [link]6[/link]). Because of this, he will be slain, and his body will be destroyed and given to the burning fire ([link]v. 11[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:20[/link]).

verse.text: I watched / Until [xref]a[/xref]thrones were set, / And the [xref]b[/xref]Ancient of Days sat down. / His clothing was like [xref]c[/xref]white [note]1[/note]snow, / And the [xref]d[/xref]hair of His head was like pure [note]1[/note]wool; / His throne was flames of [note]2[/note]fire, / Its [xref]e[/xref]wheels, burning fire.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]2[/sup] in Rev. 1[/link].

The fire here and in [link]v. 10[/link] means that God is absolutely righteous and altogether holy ([link]Heb. 12:29[/link]). Without holiness no one can see the Lord or contact Him ([link]Heb. 12:14[/link] and note).

verse.text: A [xref]a[/xref]stream of [xref]b[/xref]fire issued forth / And came out from before Him. / [xref]c[/xref]Thousands of thousands ministered to Him, / And ten thousands of ten thousands stood before Him. / The [note]1[/note]court of judgment sat, / And the [xref]d[/xref]books were opened.
verse.note: A special court, with God's throne as the center, has been set up in the universe to judge the four human empires signified by the four wild beasts ([link]v. 26[/link]). Everything that is judged by this court will be cast into the burning fire.

verse.text: I watched then because of the sound of the great things that the horn was [xref]a[/xref]speaking; I watched until the [xref]b[/xref]beast was [note]1[/note]slain and its body was destroyed and given to the burning fire.
verse.note: See note [link]8[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And as for the rest of the beasts, their dominion was taken away, but an [note]1[/note]extension of life was given to them for a season and a time.
verse.note: Although the dominion and authority of Babylon, Persia, and Greece were taken away, their life, i.e., their culture, has been extended and still remains. As each empire was defeated, its culture was adopted by each succeeding empire. Today the world's culture is Roman, yet, being an accumulated culture, it contains the cultures of the Babylonians, Persians, and Greeks.

verse.text: I watched in the night visions, / And there with the clouds of heaven / One like a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Son of Man was coming; / And He came to the [xref]b[/xref]Ancient of Days, / And they brought Him near before Him.
verse.note: Concerning His judgment, God has given all power and authority to Jesus Christ as the Son of Man ([link]John 5:22[/link], [link]27[/link]). Hence, [link]vv. 13-14[/link] describe the coming of Christ, the Son of Man. The coming here is Christ's ascension after He accomplished the work of redemption ([link]Acts 1:9[/link]; cf. [link]Rev. 5:6[/link] and note 1).

verse.text: And to Him was [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]given dominion, glory, and a [xref]b[/xref]kingdom, / That all the [xref]c[/xref]peoples, nations, and languages might serve Him. / His dominion is an eternal dominion, which will not pass away; / And His kingdom is one that will not be destroyed.
verse.note: In His ascension Christ as the Son of Man is before the throne of God to receive dominion and a kingdom. After He receives the kingdom from God, He will come back to rule over the entire world ([link]Luke 19:12[/link], [link]15[/link]). Christ's coming will terminate the entire human government on earth from its end to its beginning, and it will bring in the eternal kingdom of God ([link]2:34-35[/link], [link]44[/link]).[br/][br/]As implied in Daniel's vision, Christ accomplished redemption and then immediately came to God in ascension to receive the kingdom (cf. [link]Rev. 5:6-7[/link]). This is according to God's view, in which there is no time element. Like Abraham, David, and the other prophets, Daniel did not see the mystery of the church, which was hidden from the ages and from the generations but was revealed to the New Testament apostles and prophets ([link]Eph. 3:3-11[/link]). He did not realize that between the first and second appearings of Christ there would be a period of time during which God would do a marvelous and mysterious work based on Christ's redemption. This work is to regenerate His redeemed people and then sanctify them, renew them, transform them, and conform them to the glorious image of Christ ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 5:23[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 4:16[/link]; [link]3:18[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:29[/link]). Cf. note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 3, in Isa. 61[/link].

verse.text: As for me, Daniel, my [xref]a[/xref]spirit within me was distressed, and the visions of my head alarmed me.
I came near to one of those standing by and asked of him the exact meaning of all this. So he told me and made the interpretation of the things known to me:
These great beasts, which are four, are four kings [i]who[/i] will arise from the earth.
But the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]saints of the Most High will receive the kingdom and possess the kingdom forever, indeed, forever and ever.
verse.note: I.e., holy ones. So throughout this chapter.

verse.text: Then I wished to know the exact meaning of the [xref]a[/xref]fourth beast, which was different from all the others, exceedingly dreadful, with its teeth of iron and its claws of bronze, [i]which[/i] devoured, crushed, and trampled under the remainder with its feet,

And of the [xref]a[/xref]ten horns that were on its head, and the other [xref]b[/xref][i]horn[/i] that came up, and before which three [i]horns[/i] fell, even that horn that had eyes and a mouth speaking great things and whose appearance was greater than that of its companions.
I watched and that horn [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]waged war with the saints and prevailed against them,
verse.note: Antichrist will wage war with the saints, wear out the saints of the Most High for three and a half years, and prevail against them ([link]vv. 21[/link], [link]25[/link]; [link]Rev. 13:7a[/link] and note).

verse.text: Until the [xref]a[/xref]Ancient of Days came; and judgment was given to the saints of the Most High; and the time came when the [xref]b[/xref]saints possessed the kingdom.

Thus he said, The fourth beast will be the [xref]a[/xref]fourth kingdom upon the earth, which will be different from all the [i]other[/i] kingdoms; and it will devour the whole earth and tread it down and crush it.

And as for the [xref]a[/xref]ten horns, out of this kingdom ten kings will arise, and [xref]b[/xref]another will arise after them, and he will be different from the previous ones; and he will subdue three kings.

And he will [xref]a[/xref]speak things against the Most High and wear out the [xref]b[/xref]saints of the Most High; and his intention will be to change the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]times and the [note]1[/note]law; and they will be given into his hand for [note]2[/note]a [xref]d[/xref]time and times and half a time.
verse.note: [i]Times[/i] refers to the feasts appointed for the Jewish people ([link]Lev. 23[/link]), and [i]law[/i], to the law of God given through Moses.

[i]A time and times and half a time[/i] ([link]12:7[/link]; [link]Rev. 12:14[/link]) denotes a year (a time) plus two years (times) plus half a year (half a time), or three and a half years, i.e., forty-two months ([link]Rev. 11:2[/link]; [link]13:5[/link]), one thousand two hundred and sixty days ([link]Rev. 11:3[/link]; [link]12:6[/link]), referring to the last half of the last week prophesied in [link]9:27[/link], the time of the great tribulation ([link]Matt. 24:21[/link]).

verse.text: But the [xref]a[/xref]court of judgment will sit, and they will take away his dominion, so as to [xref]b[/xref]annihilate and destroy [i]it[/i] unto the end.

And the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom and dominion and the greatness of the kingdoms under the whole heaven will be given to the people of the saints of the Most High; His kingdom is an [xref]b[/xref]eternal kingdom, and all the dominions will serve and obey Him.
Here is the end of the matter. As for me, Daniel, my thoughts alarmed me greatly, and my countenance was changed, but I [xref]a[/xref]kept the matter in my heart.
In the [note]1[/note]third year of the reign of Belshazzar the king a [xref]a[/xref]vision appeared to me, Daniel, after the one that appeared to me at the beginning.
verse.note: Cf. note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].

verse.text: And I looked in the vision, and while I looked, now I was in the fortress of [xref]a[/xref]Shushan, which is in the province of Elam; and while I looked in the vision, I was beside the river Ulai.

Then I lifted my eyes, and I looked, and there was a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]ram, standing before the river, and he had two horns. And the two horns were high, but one was higher than the other; and the higher one came up last.
verse.note: The ram, corresponding to the second beast in [link]7:5[/link] and to the breast and arms of silver of the great human image in [link]ch. 2[/link], signifies Medo-Persia ([link]v. 20[/link]; [link]11:2[/link]). Its two horns signify Media and Persia. Persia with its king Cyrus ([link]Ezra 1:1[/link]), which came up last, became higher than Media.

verse.text: I saw the ram [note]1[/note]pushing westward, northward, and southward; and no beast could stand before him, and there was no one who could deliver from his power; but he [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]did as he pleased, and he became great.
verse.note: This signifies that Medo-Persia conquered Babylon to the west, Assyria to the north, and Egypt to the south.

This indicates that Medo-Persia had no fear of God and became arrogant in itself. Eventually, God dealt with Medo-Persia by raising up Alexander the Great. Cf. note [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in Zech. 1[/link].

verse.text: And while I considered [i]this,[/i] there was a [note]1[/note]male goat, coming from the west over the face of the whole earth without touching the ground; and the goat had a [note]2[/note]conspicuous [xref]a[/xref]horn between his eyes.
verse.note: The male goat, corresponding to the third beast in [link]7:6[/link] and to the abdomen and thighs of bronze of the great human image in [link]ch. 2[/link], signifies Greece with Alexander the Great ([link]v. 21a[/link]; [link]11:3[/link]). Its coming from the west signifies that it came from Europe. Its coming over the face of the whole earth without touching the ground signifies its swift movement over the earth.
This signifies Alexander the Great as an extraordinary horn distinguished by his two sharp eyes. He was very intelligent.

verse.text: And he came up to the ram that had the two horns, which I had seen standing before the river, and ran toward him in his mighty wrath.

And I saw him come close to the ram, and he was enraged at him; and he struck the ram and [note]1[/note]broke his two horns; and the ram had no strength to withstand him, but [i]the goat[/i] threw him down to the ground and trampled him; and there was none to deliver the ram from his power.
verse.note: This indicates that Alexander the Great conquered Medo-Persia and destroyed it.

verse.text: And the male goat became very [note]1[/note]great. But once he became strong, the great horn was [note]1[/note]broken, and in its place [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]four conspicuous ones came up toward the four winds of heaven.
verse.note: Alexander the Great became arrogant in himself. But as soon as he became strong in power, he died suddenly.

In the place of Alexander the Great, his four generals (corresponding to the four wings and the four heads in [link]7:6[/link]), Cassander, Lysimachus, Ptolemy, and Seleucus, rose up toward the four ends of his empire to form nations in Macedonia, Asia Minor, Egypt, and Syria, respectively ([link]v. 22[/link]). This was the continuation of the Grecian Empire. Eventually, these four empires were merged and formed into two empires, one on the south (Egypt) and the other on the north (Syria). [link]Chapter 11[/link] describes the warfare between these two empires in the territory of Israel.

verse.text: And out of one of them came forth a [note]1[/note]little [xref]a[/xref]horn, which grew very great toward the [xref]b[/xref]south, toward the east, and toward that which is [xref]c[/xref]beautiful.
verse.note: Or, a horn out of littleness. This horn signifies Antiochus IV Epiphanes from Syria, who ruled in 175-164 B.C. He expanded very much toward Egypt on the south, toward Syria on the east, and toward Israel, the beautiful land ([link]11:16[/link]).

verse.text: And it grew great, [note]1[/note]as high as the [xref]a[/xref]host of heaven; and it caused some of the host and some of the [xref]b[/xref]stars to fall to the earth, and it trampled them.
verse.note: The little horn growing great, as high as the host of heaven, and causing some of the host and some of the stars to fall to the earth, and trampling them ([link]11:30b-35[/link]), signifies that he became great in power and persecuted the saints (signified by the host of heaven and the stars — [link]12:3[/link]). In all these evil things he typifies the coming Antichrist ([link]Rev. 13:5-7[/link]; [link]2 Thes. 2:3b-4[/link]).

verse.text: Indeed, he grew in greatness to [i]that of[/i] the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Prince of the host; and [note]2[/note]from Him the [xref]b[/xref]daily sacrifice was [xref]c[/xref]taken away, and the place of His [xref]d[/xref]sanctuary was thrown down.
verse.note: Signifying God.

Or, by him; i.e., the little horn. Antiochus Epiphanes stopped the daily sacrifices in the temple and defiled the temple with pigs and with fornication ([link]11:31[/link]).
