Furthermore, he cast truth to the ground ([link]v. 12[/link]), meaning that there was no righteousness or justice. In these evils also the little horn typifies Antichrist ([link]9:27[/link]).

verse.text: And an army was given [i]to him[/i] together with the daily sacrifice because of transgression; and he cast truth down to the ground, and he took action and prospered.

Then I heard a [note]1[/note]holy one speaking; and another [note]1[/note]holy one said to the particular one who was speaking, How long will the vision [i]concerning[/i] the daily sacrifice and the [xref]a[/xref]transgression that desolates apply, so that the sanctuary and the host are trampled down?
verse.note: Or, saint.

verse.text: And he said to me, For [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]two thousand three hundred nights and days; then the sanctuary will be [note]2[/note]cleansed.
verse.note: The days for Antiochus Epiphanes to do evil things in the Holy Land would extend from about 171 B.C. until December 25, 165 B.C., the day when the Jewish hero Judas Maccabeus would cleanse the sanctuary after defeating Antiochus Epiphanes ([link]vv. 25b-26[/link]). See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in John 10[/link].
Lit., justified. The cleansing of the temple by the Maccabees was a justification, declaring that the temple was the holy place for God's people to worship Him.

verse.text: And when I, Daniel, had seen the vision, I sought an understanding [i]of it;[/i] and immediately [i]there was[/i] someone with an appearance like that of a man standing before me.
And I heard the voice of a man between [i]the banks of[/i] the Ulai; and He called out and said, [xref]a[/xref]Gabriel, cause this man to understand the vision.

So he came near to where I stood; and when he came, I was afraid, and I [xref]a[/xref]fell on my face; but he said to me, Understand, O son of man, that the vision pertains to the [xref]b[/xref]end time.
And as he was speaking with me, I fell into a deep [xref]a[/xref]sleep on my face upon the ground; but he [xref]b[/xref]touched me and made me stand in my place.
And he said, I now make known to you what will happen at the end of the indignation, for [i]the vision[/i] pertains to the appointed time of the [xref]a[/xref]end.
The [xref]a[/xref]ram that you saw, which had the two horns, are the kings of Media and Persia.
And the hairy [xref]a[/xref]goat is the king of [note]1[/note]Javan; and the great horn which was between its eyes is the first [xref]b[/xref]king.
verse.note: I.e., Greece.

verse.text: And the broken [i]horn[/i] and the [xref]a[/xref]four [i]horns[/i] that arose in its place are four kingdoms that will arise from [i]his[/i] nation, but not with his power.

And in the latter time of their kingdom, / When the transgressors have [xref]a[/xref]filled up [i]their transgressions,[/i] / A [note]1[/note]king will [xref]b[/xref]arise, / [note]2[/note]Of fierce countenance and skilled in [note]3[/note]ambiguities.
verse.note: The little horn, Antiochus Epiphanes ([link]v. 9[/link]).
I.e., impudent (cf. [link]Deut. 28:50[/link]).

Antiochus Epiphanes spoke in such a manner that his word could be interpreted in many different ways. In all the items mentioned in [link]vv. 23-25[/link], he typifies Antichrist ([link]Rev. 13:2b[/link], [link]6-7[/link]; [link]17:11[/link], [link]14[/link]; [link]19:20[/link]).

verse.text: And his power will be mighty, but not by his [i]own[/i] [xref]a[/xref]power. / And he will destroy in an extraordinary manner / And will prosper and take action. / He will destroy mighty men / And the [xref]b[/xref]holy people.

Through his craftiness / He will also cause [xref]a[/xref]deceit to prosper in his hand; / And he will [xref]b[/xref]magnify [i]himself[/i] in his heart; / And he will destroy many [i]who are[/i] complacently secure. / And against the [xref]c[/xref]Prince of princes he will stand up; / But he will be [xref]d[/xref]broken, [i]yet[/i] not by [i]human[/i] hands.
And the vision of the evenings and the mornings, / Which has been told, is true. / But [xref]a[/xref]shut the vision up, / For it pertains to [i]something[/i] many days [i]from now.[/i]
Then I, Daniel, was spent, and I was sick for days. Then I arose and conducted the king's affairs; but I was astonished at the vision, and there was no one to explain [i]it.[/i]
In the first year of [xref]a[/xref]Darius the son of Ahasuerus, a Median descendant who was made king over the kingdom of the Chaldeans,

In the first year of his reign[separator]I, Daniel, understood by means of the [note]1[/note]Scriptures the number of the years, which came as the word of Jehovah to Jeremiah the prophet, for the completion of the desolations of Jerusalem, [i]that is,[/i] [xref]a[/xref]seventy years.
verse.note: Or, the books. Daniel's understanding of the prophecies in [link]Jer. 25:11-12[/link] and [link]29:10-14[/link], concerning the seventy years of Israel's captivity before the return of a remnant to Jerusalem ([link]2 Chron. 36:21-23[/link]), was the cause of the vision of the seventy weeks given to Daniel in this chapter.

verse.text: So I set my face toward the Lord God to [note]1[/note]seek [i]Him[/i] in [xref]a[/xref]prayer and supplications with fasting and sackcloth and ashes.
verse.note: Daniel was in captivity in Babylon ([link]vv. 1-2a[/link]); his heart was fully set on God and His people, His temple, and His holy city for God's kingdom on earth ([link]vv. 2b-19[/link]); and he was in his spirit, fully occupied with prayer and supplications to God ([link]vv. 20-23[/link]). Thus, he had the proper standing and a proper angle to receive the revelation and see the vision from God (cf. notes [link book="Rev." chapter="1"]9[sup]3[/sup][/link], [link]10[sup]1[/sup][/link], and [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in Rev. 1[/link]).

verse.text: And I prayed to Jehovah my God and confessed; and I said, Ah, Lord, the [xref]a[/xref]great and awesome God, who keeps covenant and [xref]b[/xref]lovingkindness with those who love Him and keep His commandments,
We have [xref]a[/xref]sinned and have committed iniquity, and we have acted wickedly and rebelled, [i]to the point of[/i] even turning away from Your commandments and from Your judgments.
And we have not listened to Your servants the prophets, who spoke in Your name to our kings, our chief men, and our fathers, as well as to all the people of the land.

To You, Lord, belongs righteousness, but to us, shamefacedness, as it is this day, [i]that is,[/i] to the men of Judah and to the inhabitants of Jerusalem and to all Israel, those who are near and those who are far off in all the lands to which You have driven them because of their trespass by which they have trespassed against You.
O Jehovah, to us belongs shamefacedness, to our kings, our chief men, and our fathers, because we have sinned against You.
To the Lord our God belong compassion and forgiveness, for we have rebelled against Him;
And we have not obeyed the voice of Jehovah our God, to walk in His instruction, which He set before us through the hand of His servants the prophets.

Indeed, all Israel has transgressed Your law, [i]to the point of[/i] even turning away so as not to obey Your voice; thus the [xref]a[/xref]curse has been poured out upon us, the very oath that is written in the law of Moses the servant of God, for we have sinned against Him.

And He has confirmed His words which He [xref]a[/xref]spoke against us and against our judges who judged us, by bringing upon us great ill; for under all heaven there has not been done anything like that which [xref]b[/xref]has been done in Jerusalem.
As it is written in the law of Moses, all this ill has come upon us, yet we have not entreated the favor of Jehovah our God by turning from our iniquities and attending to Your truth.
Therefore Jehovah has been vigilant with the ill and has brought it upon us, for Jehovah our God is righteous in all the deeds that He has done, but we have not obeyed His voice.

And now, O Lord our God, who have [xref]a[/xref]brought Your people out of the land of Egypt with a mighty hand and have made for Yourself a name, as it is this day, we have sinned, we have been wicked.

O Lord, in accordance with all the [note]1[/note]manifestations of Your righteousness, may Your anger and Your wrath be turned away, I pray, from Your city Jerusalem, Your holy [xref]a[/xref]mountain; for because of our sins and the iniquities of our fathers, Jerusalem and Your people are a reproach to all those around us.
verse.note: Lit., Your righteousnesses.

verse.text: And now hear, O our God, the prayer of Your servant and his supplications, and cause Your face to [xref]a[/xref]shine upon Your sanctuary that has been desolated, for the Lord's sake.

O my God, incline Your ear and [xref]a[/xref]hear; open Your eyes and see our desolations and the city that is called by Your name; for we are not presenting our supplications before You based upon any righteous doings that we have done, but based upon Your great compassion.
O Lord, hear! O Lord, forgive! O Lord, listen and take action! Do not delay, for Your own sake, O my God; for Your city and Your people are called by Your [i]own[/i] name.
And while I was still speaking and praying and [xref]a[/xref]confessing my sin and the sin of my people Israel and presenting my supplication before Jehovah my God for the holy mountain of my God,

Even while I was speaking in prayer, the man [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Gabriel, whom I had seen in the vision at the beginning, reached [i]me[/i] in my utter exhaustion about the time of the [xref]b[/xref]evening oblation.
verse.note: In his desperate prayer Daniel confessed his own sins and the sins of his people Israel ([link]vv. 3-15[/link]) and requested that God recover the Holy Land, send His people back, and rebuild the holy city ([link]vv. 16-19[/link]). God answered him by giving him the report through the angel Gabriel of the seventy weeks ([link]vv. 20-27[/link]). This answer exceeded what Daniel requested.

verse.text: And he informed [i]me[/i] and talked with me and said, Daniel, I have now come forth to give you insight with understanding.

At the beginning of your supplications the command went forth, and I have come to tell [i]you,[/i] for you are [xref]a[/xref]preciousness itself. Therefore understand the matter, and consider the vision.

[note]1[/note]Seventy weeks are apportioned for your people and for your holy city, to close the transgression, and to [note]2[/note]make an end of sins, and to make [xref]a[/xref]propitiation for iniquity, and to bring in the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]righteousness of the ages, and to [note]4[/note]seal up vision and prophet, and to [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]anoint the Holy of Holies.
verse.note: The contents of Daniel's vision are the seventy weeks, which are the destiny apportioned by God for His people and for His holy city. The purpose of the seventy weeks is to close the transgression, to make an end of sins, to make propitiation for iniquity, to bring in the righteousness of the ages, to seal up vision and prophet, and to anoint the Holy of Holies. In the old creation under human government, transgression, sins, and iniquity are prevailing. When Christ comes to crush human government ([link]2:34-35[/link]), at the time appointed, the transgression will be closed, sins will be ended, and iniquity will be propitiated. Then the righteousness of the ages will be brought in, the vision and prophet will be sealed, and the Holy of Holies will be anointed.
Or, seal up.

When Christ returns and the age is consummated, there will be no more unrighteousness on the earth. After the Lord's return all the evil persons and things on earth will be swept into the lake of fire ([link]Matt. 13:30[/link]; [link]25:32-33[/link], [link]41[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:19-21[/link]), and Satan will be bound and cast into the abyss ([link]Rev. 20:1-3[/link]). At the end of the millennium the deceived nations (with Satan) will be removed in the last rebellion of mankind against God ([link]Rev. 20:7-10[/link]), and after the millennium the dead unbelievers and the demons will be cleared away through the judgment at the great white throne ([link]Rev. 20:11-15[/link]). Beginning with the millennium there will be the eternal kingdom of Christ with His righteousness, which is the righteousness of the ages, the eternal righteousness. In the millennium Christ will be the righteous One ([link]Jer. 23:5[/link]), and He will rule the thousand-year kingdom in righteousness ([link]Isa. 11:4-5[/link]). Ultimately, in the age of the ages, righteousness will dwell in the new heaven and new earth for eternity ([link]2 Pet. 3:13[/link] and note 3).

To seal up vision and prophet is to close the age of mystery at the sounding of the seventh trumpet ([link]Rev. 10:7[/link] and note 2). Since all the mysteries of God will be fulfilled, there will be no need of visions or prophets. In the kingdom age there will be kings and priests ([link]Rev. 20:6[/link]) but no prophets.

At the time of Daniel's prayer, the Holy of Holies was contaminated, defiled, and devastated. But when the apportioned time comes, the Holy of Holies will be properly anointed. This means that the service to God will be recovered (see note [link]31[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 11[/link], and notes [link chapter="12"]11[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link]).

verse.text: Know therefore and comprehend: From the issuing of the decree to [xref]a[/xref]restore and rebuild Jerusalem until [i]the time of[/i] [xref]b[/xref]Messiah the [xref]c[/xref]Prince will be [note]1[/note]seven weeks and [note]1[/note]sixty-two weeks; it will be built again, with [note]2[/note]street and trench, even in distressful times.
verse.note: The seventy weeks are divided into three parts, each week being seven years in length (see "The Chart of the Seventy Weeks and the Coming of Christ, with the Rapture of the Saints"). First, seven weeks (forty-nine years) were apportioned from the issuing of the decree to restore and rebuild Jerusalem ([link]Neh. 2:1-8[/link]) to the completion of the rebuilding. Second, sixty-two weeks (434 years) were apportioned from the completion of the rebuilding of Jerusalem to the cutting off (crucifixion) of the Messiah ([link]v. 26[/link]). Third, the last week of seven years will be for Antichrist to make a firm covenant with the people of Israel ([link]v. 27[/link]).[br/][br/]There is a gap of unknown duration between the first sixty-nine weeks and the last week of the seventy weeks. This gap is the age of mystery, the age of grace, the age of the church ([link]Eph. 3:3-11[/link]; [link]5:32[/link]; [link]Col. 1:27[/link]). During this age Christ is secretly and mysteriously building up the church in the new creation to be His Body and His bride ([link]Eph. 5:25-32[/link]). When the new creation has become mature in life, it will be attached to Christ and become one with Him to be His counterpart ([link]Rev. 19:7-9[/link]). At the end of the last week of the seventy weeks, after Christ has married His bride, He with His bridal army will come as the stone cut out without hands and will crush the great human image from the toes to the head, destroying the human government that fights against God directly. Through this crushing the problem of human government in the old creation will be solved. Then Christ with His overcomers will increase to become a great mountain that fills the whole earth ([link]2:34-35[/link] and notes).
Referring to the wide open plaza of the city or the free open space before the temple; hence, the street.

verse.text: And after the sixty-two weeks Messiah will be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]cut off and will have nothing; and the [xref]b[/xref]people of the [note]2[/note]prince who will come will destroy the city and the [xref]c[/xref]sanctuary; and the end of it will be with a flood, and even to the end [i]there will be[/i] [note]3[/note]war; desolations are determined.
verse.note: This refers to the crucifixion of Christ, which was the termination of the old creation, with the human government in the old creation, and the germination of God's new creation through the resurrection of Christ ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]), with God's eternal kingdom as the divine administration in God's new creation. Thus, the cross of Christ is the centrality and universality of God's work.[br/][br/]The book of Daniel bears a particular characteristic: to draw the marking lines of the ages. First, the crucifixion of Christ in His first appearing is the landmark that terminated the age of the old creation for the germination of the age of the new creation in Christ's resurrection. In His crucifixion Christ, the last Adam, terminated the old creation ([link]2 Cor. 5:14[/link]), and in His resurrection He became the germinating Spirit, the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]), to germinate all God's chosen people in His resurrection ([link]John 12:24[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]) to be God's new creation ([link]2 Cor. 5:17[/link]; [link]Gal. 6:15[/link]). This new creation begins with the believers in Christ as God's sons ([link]Gal. 3:26[/link]) and as Christ's members who constitute His Body ([link]1 Cor. 12:27[/link]). This Body will grow ([link]Eph. 4:13-16[/link]) and will eventually consummate in the New Jerusalem ([link]Rev. 21-22[/link]). Second, the upcoming appearing of Christ with His overcomers as His bride will be the landmark that will end the age of man's government on earth in the old creation and will initiate the age of God's dominion over the entire earth in the millennium and in the new heaven and new earth for eternity ([link]2:34-35[/link], [link]44[/link]; [link]7:13-14[/link]). Although in His first appearing Christ terminated the old creation spiritually through His death on the cross, the human government that began with Nimrod continues to exist. For this reason there is the need of Christ's second appearing, in which Christ will clear up the human government in the old creation physically and will usher in the universal and eternal kingdom of God. By Christ's appearing in these two aspects, and by the ruling of the heavens over all the environment on earth, Christ, who is the centrality and universality of God's economy and of God's move, will become the centrality and universality of God's elect, including Israel and the church.
Titus, the prince of the Roman Empire, who came with his army in A.D. 70 to destroy the city and the sanctuary, the temple, as prophesied by the Lord Jesus in [link]Matt. 24:2[/link].
From the destruction of Jerusalem in A.D. 70 until the seventy weeks are completed, there has been and will be war after war.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]he will make a firm covenant with the many for one week; and in the [xref]a[/xref]middle of the week he will cause the sacrifice and the oblation to cease and [note]2[/note]will replace the sacrifice and the oblation with [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]abominations of the desolator, even until the complete destruction that has been determined is poured out upon the desolator.
verse.note: Referring to Antichrist, typified here by Titus, the prince mentioned in [link]v. 26[/link]. At the beginning of the last week of the seventy weeks, the last seven years of the present age, Antichrist will make a firm covenant of peace with Israel. In the middle of that week he will break the covenant and will cause the sacrifice and oblation to cease ([link]12:11a[/link]). This will be the beginning of the great tribulation ([link]Matt. 24:21[/link]), which will last for three and a half years ([link]7:25[/link]; [link]12:7[/link]; [link]Rev. 11:2-3[/link]; [link]12:6[/link], [link]14[/link]; [link]13:5[/link]). During the great tribulation both the faithful Jews and the Christians still on earth will suffer Antichrist's persecution ([link]7:21[/link], [link]25[/link]; [link]Rev. 13:7[/link]). After he causes the sacrifice and the oblation to cease, Antichrist will replace them with the abominations of the desolator (the idols of Antichrist — [link]12:11[/link]; [link]Matt. 24:15[/link]; [link]Rev. 13:14-15[/link]; [link]2 Thes. 2:4[/link]). These idols will remain in the temple for three and a half years, even until the complete destruction that has been determined is poured out upon the desolator, Antichrist ([link]2:34-35a[/link]; [link]2 Thes. 2:8[/link]; [link]Rev. 17:14[/link]; [link]19:20[/link]).[br/][br/]The fact that the temple will be devastated and contaminated by Antichrist strongly indicates that the temple, which has not been rebuilt since it was destroyed by Titus and the Roman army in A.D. 70, will be rebuilt by the Jews before the completion of the seventy weeks. This will be one of the final signs that will take place before Christ's return.
Lit., upon the wing of abominations will be a desolator. The meaning of the Hebrew is uncertain; the translation offered is based on the events recorded in [link]11:31[/link].
See notes [link book="Matt." chapter="24"]15[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]15[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 24[/link].

verse.text: In the [note]1[/note]third year of [xref]a[/xref]Cyrus the king of Persia a word was revealed to Daniel, who was named [xref]b[/xref]Belteshazzar;[separator]and the word was true and [i]concerning[/i] a great [note]2[/note]distress. And he understood the word and had an understanding of the vision.
verse.note: About 537 B.C., two years after the issuing of the decree by Cyrus to release the captives of Israel that they might return to the land of their forefathers and rebuild the temple ([link]Ezra 1:1-4[/link]). See note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

Or, conflict, warfare. The main subject of the vision in this chapter concerning the destiny of Israel is the great distress, which came upon Israel because of a war between the king of the south (Egypt) and the king of the north (Syria). The two kings waged war against each other on Israel's land, using it as a thoroughfare to invade each other ([link]11:2-35[/link]). These wars were a distress, a trial, to the children of Israel. This was especially true of the war that was waged by Antiochus Epiphanes, king of Syria, a descendant of one of the four successors of Alexander the Great and a full type of Antichrist. This was a severe trial sent by God to His chosen people because they had become corrupt after their return from captivity.

verse.text: In those days I, Daniel, had been mourning for [note]1[/note]three full weeks.
verse.note: For twenty-one days Daniel, a man on the earth, set his heart to understand the future, the destiny, of Israel ([link]vv. 2-3[/link], [link]12[/link]).

verse.text: I ate no desirable food, nor did meat or wine enter my mouth, nor did I [xref]a[/xref]anoint myself at all, until the three full weeks were completed.
And on the twenty-fourth day of the first month, while I was by the great river, that is, the [note]1[/note]Hiddekel,
verse.note: I.e., the Tigris.

verse.text: I lifted up my eyes and I looked, and there was a certain [note]1[/note]man, [xref]a[/xref]clothed in linen, whose loins were [xref]b[/xref]girded with the fine gold of Uphaz.
verse.note: Before the vision concerning the destiny of Israel was unveiled to Daniel, he was given a vision of the spiritual scene that is behind the physical situation ([link]10:2-11:1[/link]). In this spiritual scene Christ is preeminent; hence, He is revealed first ([link]vv. 4-9[/link]). Here the excellent Christ appeared to Daniel as a man for his appreciation, consolation, encouragement, expectation, and stabilization (cf. notes [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Gen. 18[/link] and [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in Judg. 13[/link]). He appeared to Daniel with many wonderful characteristics. First, He appeared as a Priest in His humanity, signified by the linen robe ([link]Exo. 28:31-35[/link]), to care for His chosen people in their captivity. Second, He appeared to Daniel in His kingship in His divinity, signified by the girdle of gold, for ruling over all the peoples. Furthermore, for His people's appreciation Christ appeared in His preciousness and dignity, as signified by His body being like beryl ([link]v. 6a[/link]). The Hebrew word for beryl could refer to a bluish-green or yellow precious stone, signifying that Christ in His embodiment is divine (yellow), full of life (green), and heavenly (blue). Christ also appeared in His brightness for shining over the people, as signified by His face being like the appearance of lightning ([link]v. 6b[/link]), and in His enlightening sight for searching and judging, as signified by His eyes being like torches of fire ([link]v. 6c[/link]). Moreover, Christ appeared in the gleam of His work and move, as signified by His arms and His feet being like the gleam of polished bronze ([link]v. 6d[/link]). Finally, Christ appeared to Daniel in His strong speaking for judging people, as signified by the sound of His words being like the sound of a multitude ([link]v. 6e[/link]). As a man, the very centrality and universality of God's move on earth for the carrying out of His economy, such a Christ is precious, valuable, complete, and perfect. Cf. [link]Rev. 1:13-16[/link] and notes.

verse.text: His body also was like [xref]a[/xref]beryl, His face like the appearance of [xref]b[/xref]lightning, His eyes like torches of [xref]c[/xref]fire, His arms and His feet like the gleam of polished [xref]d[/xref]bronze, and the [xref]e[/xref]sound of His words like the sound of a multitude.
And I, Daniel, [note]1[/note]alone saw the vision, for the men who were with me did [xref]a[/xref]not see the vision; instead, a great dread fell on them, and they fled to hide themselves.
verse.note: Because the vision of Christ was spiritual, not physical, it was seen only by Daniel and not by those who relied on their physical sight. In seeing the vision of Christ, the physical view avails nothing (cf. [link]Matt. 16:16-17[/link]; [link]Acts 9:1-9[/link]; [link]Gal. 1:15-16[/link]).

verse.text: Thus I was left alone and I saw this great vision; and no strength was left in me, but my color turned [note]1[/note]deathly pale; and I retained no strength.
verse.note: Lit., to destruction.

verse.text: Yet I heard the sound of His words; and when I heard the sound of His words, I fell into a deep sleep on my face, with my face to the ground.
And at that moment a hand [xref]a[/xref]touched me and sent me trembling on my knees and the palms of my hands.

And [note]1[/note]he said to me, Daniel, man of [xref]a[/xref]preciousness, understand the words that I am about to tell you and stand in your place, for I have now been sent to you. And when he had spoken this word to me, I stood up trembling.
verse.note: After the vision of Christ, an angelic messenger (he might have been Gabriel — [link]8:16[/link]; [link]9:21[/link]; cf. [link]Luke 1:19[/link], [link]26[/link]) came to Daniel in answer to his prayer ([link]v. 12[/link]). He told Daniel that for twenty-one days he himself had been fighting against the prince of the kingdom of Persia ([link]v. 13[/link], cf. [link]v. 20a[/link]), probably an evil spirit, a rebellious angel, who followed Satan in his rebellion against God ([link]Rev. 12:4a[/link], [link]9b[/link]) and who was commissioned by Satan to help Persia. Thus, while Daniel was praying during those days, a spiritual struggle was taking place in the air between two spirits, one belonging to Satan and the other belonging to God. Another evil spirit, the prince of Greece (Javan), was about to come ([link]v. 20b[/link]). Only the archangel Michael, a prince fighting for Israel, fought together with the angelic messenger against the evil spirits ([link]vv. 13[/link], [link]21[/link]; cf. [link]Jude 9[/link]). Moreover, the angelic messenger stood up to support and strengthen Darius the Mede in the first year of his reign in order that he might receive the kingdom ([link]11:1[/link]; [link]5:30-31[/link]). All this indicates that behind the physical scene a spiritual struggle, an invisible spiritual war, was taking place (cf. [link]Eph. 6:10-20[/link]). See note [link]12[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in Isa. 14[/link].

verse.text: And he said to me, Do not be afraid, Daniel, for from the first day that you [xref]a[/xref]set your heart to understand [i]this matter[/i] and to afflict yourself before your God, your words were [xref]b[/xref]heard; and I have come because of your words.

But the prince of the kingdom of Persia withstood me for twenty-one days; but now [xref]a[/xref]Michael, one of the chief princes, came to help me, for I remained there [i]alone[/i] with the kings of Persia.
Thus I have come to make you understand what will happen to your people in the last days, yet the vision pertains to [i]something many days from now.[/i]
And when he had spoken to me according to these words, I turned my face to the ground and was dumb.

And at that moment one who resembled the sons of men touched my lips; and I opened my mouth and spoke, and I said to him who stood before me, Sir, because of the vision my anguish has turned upon me, and I have retained no strength.
For how can such a servant of my lord speak with such as my lord? For as for me, just now there is no strength in me, nor has there been breath left in me.
Then the one who was in appearance like a man touched me again and strengthened me;
And he said, Do not be afraid, man of preciousness. Peace to you. Be strong, yes, be strong. And when he spoke to me, I received strength and said, Speak, sir, for you have strengthened me.
Then he said, Do you know why I have come to you? And now I will return to fight with the prince of Persia; so I go forth, and the prince of [note]1[/note]Javan is now about to come.
verse.note: I.e., Greece.

verse.text: However I will tell you what is inscribed in the writing of truth. Yet there is no one who holds strongly with me against these ones except [xref]a[/xref]Michael your prince.
And [note]1[/note]I, in the first year of [xref]a[/xref]Darius the Mede, stood up to support and strengthen him.
verse.note: The angelic messenger in [link]ch. 10[/link]; see note [link]11[sup]1[/sup][/link] there.

verse.text: And now I will tell you the [note]1[/note]truth. There will yet arise three kings in Persia; then the [xref]a[/xref]fourth will gain great riches, more than all [i]of them;[/i] and once he becomes strong because of his riches, he will stir up the whole [i]empire[/i] against the realm of [note]2[/note]Javan.
verse.note: The contents of the vision in this chapter concern the destiny of Israel from the last part of the kingdom of Persia to the last three and a half years of the present age, even extending to the kingdom age and eternity, as the truth that was inscribed in the writing of truth ([link]10:21[/link]), told to Daniel by the angelic messenger ([link]11:2-12:13[/link]). The vision in this chapter provides further details regarding the Persian Empire, the Grecian Empire, and the Roman Empire, to the very end of the Roman Empire under Antichrist in the last three and a half years of this age (see note [link]32[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 2[/link]).
I.e., Greece.

verse.text: And a [note]1[/note]mighty [xref]a[/xref]king will arise [i]there,[/i] and he will rule with great dominion and do as he pleases.
verse.note: I.e., Alexander the Great ([link]8:5-8a[/link], [link]20-21[/link]; [link]7:5-6a[/link]), the king of Greece, who defeated Persia in about 333 B.C.

verse.text: But once he arises, his kingdom will be [note]1[/note]broken and divided toward the [xref]a[/xref]four winds of heaven, but not to his posterity, nor according to his dominion with which he ruled; for his kingdom will be plucked up and [i]given[/i] to others besides [note]2[/note]his descendants.
verse.note: Shortly after defeating the kingdom of Persia, Alexander the Great died, and his kingdom was divided into four kingdoms under his four generals ([link]8:8b[/link], [link]22[/link]; [link]7:6b[/link]). Two of these kingdoms, Egypt and Syria, fought wars back and forth through the land of Israel. Eventually, this chapter stresses the kingdoms and evils of two kings: Antiochus Epiphanes, one of the kings of the north ([link]vv. 21-35[/link]), and Antichrist, the king of the restored Roman Empire ([link]vv. 36-45[/link]).
Lit., these.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]king of the south will become strong, as well as [i]one[/i] of his princes, who will grow in strength above him and have dominion; his dominion will be a great dominion.
verse.note: [link]Verses 5-20[/link] speak of the wars fought back and forth between the king of the south (Egypt) and the king of the north (Syria). As these kings fought each other, they passed through Israel. Thus, Israel was in distress ([link]10:1[/link]).

verse.text: And at the end of some years they will join themselves together. And the daughter of the king of the south will go to the king of the north and make a treaty; but she will not retain the strength of her arm, nor will he and his arm stand; but she will be given up, along with those who brought her [i]into the alliance[/i] and him who begot her and supported her in those times.
But a shoot from her roots will arise in his place, and he will come against the army and enter into the fortress of the king of the north; and he will deal with them and show his strength.

And also their gods with their cast images, with their precious vessels of silver and gold, he will carry off into captivity in Egypt; and for [i]some[/i] years he will refrain from the king of the north.
And [note]1[/note]the king of the north will come to the kingdom of the king of the south, but he will return to his [i]own[/i] land.
verse.note: Lit., he.

verse.text: But his sons will stir themselves up to war and will gather a multitude of great forces; and one will come unrelentingly and will overflow and pass through and will return and wage war, [i]even[/i] up to the fortress of [note]1[/note]the king of the south.
verse.note: Lit., him.

verse.text: And the king of the south will be enraged and will come forth to fight with him, with the king of the north. Then [note]1[/note]the king of the north will raise up a great multitude, but the multitude will be given into the hand of [note]2[/note]the king of the south.
verse.note: Lit., he.
Lit., him.

verse.text: When the multitude is carried away, the heart of [note]1[/note]the king of the south will be lifted up; and he will cast down tens of thousands, but he will not prevail.
verse.note: Lit., him.

verse.text: For the king of the north will return, and he will raise up a multitude greater than the first; and at the end of some years he will come unrelentingly with a great army and with much materiel.
And in those times many will rise up against the king of the south; and the violent ones of your people will lift themselves up to establish the vision, but they will fall.

Then the [note]1[/note]king of the north will come and cast up a siege mound and capture the fortified city; and the forces of the south will not stand, nor his choice people, for there will be no strength to stand.
verse.note: The prophecy in [link]vv. 15-19[/link] concerns Antiochus the Great (the father of Antiochus Epiphanes), who defeated Egypt in 200 B.C. and was eventually killed in a revolt in 187 B.C.

verse.text: But he who comes against [note]1[/note]the king of the south will do as he pleases; and no one will stand before him. And he will stand in the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]beautiful land, and destruction will be in his hand.
verse.note: Lit., him.
I.e., the land of Israel.

verse.text: And he will set his face to come with the strength of his whole kingdom, and with him [i]there will be[/i] [note]1[/note]terms of peace that he will act upon. And he will give [note]2[/note]the king of the south a youthful daughter, to destroy it; yet she will not be able to stand [i]for him,[/i] but will be of no use to him.
verse.note: Lit., upright things.
Lit., him.

verse.text: Then he will turn his face to the [note]1[/note]coastlands and will capture many. But a leader, for his own sake, will put an end to the reproach caused by him; indeed, he will turn his reproach back on him.
verse.note: I.e., the islands and shores of the Mediterranean Sea.

verse.text: Then [note]1[/note]the king of the north will turn his face to the fortresses of his own land, but he will stumble and fall and will not be found.
verse.note: Lit., he.

verse.text: Then there will arise in his place one who will cause an oppressor to pass through the [note]1[/note]splendor of the kingdom; yet within a few days he will be broken, but not while [i]venting his[/i] anger nor [i]pursuing[/i] battle.
verse.note: I.e., Judea, or more specifically, Jerusalem.

verse.text: Then there will arise in his place a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]despicable person, to whom the honor of a kingdom will not be given; but he will come in a time of security and will seize the kingdom by smooth and cunning words and actions.
verse.note: I.e., Antiochus Epiphanes. [link]Verses 21-35[/link] and [link]8:23-25[/link] describe the kingdom and the evils of Antiochus Epiphanes as one of the kings of the north. He is emphasized in this chapter because, as a full type of Antichrist, he did much to damage and defile the temple ([link]v. 31[/link]).

verse.text: And the overflowing forces will be flooded over before him and broken, even also the [note]1[/note]prince of the covenant.
verse.note: I.e., the prince allied to him.

verse.text: And once he has made an alliance with him, he will practice [xref]a[/xref]deceit and will go up and become mighty with a small [i]group of[/i] people.

In a time of security he will enter even the richest parts of the kingdom and will do that which his fathers never did, nor his fathers' fathers; prey, spoil, and riches will he scatter among them, and against strongholds he will devise strategies, but [i]only[/i] for a while.

And he will stir up his power and his heart against the king of the south with a great army; and the king of the south will stir himself up to wage war with an extremely great and mighty army [i]of his own;[/i] but he will not stand, for strategies will have been devised against him.
And those who eat of his choice provision will destroy him; and his army will overflow, and many will fall down slain.

And as for both of these kings, their hearts will be to do evil, and they will speak lies across one table; but [i]what they do[/i] will not succeed, for the [xref]a[/xref]end is still at the appointed time.
Then [note]1[/note]the king of the north will return to his land with great riches; but his heart will be [i]set[/i] against the holy covenant, and he will take action and will return to his land.
verse.note: Lit., he.

verse.text: At the appointed time he will return and come against the south; but this latter time will not be like the former time.

For ships of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Kittim will come against him; therefore he will be disheartened and will turn away; and he will be enraged at the holy covenant and will take action. When he turns away, he will focus his attention on those who forsake the holy covenant.
verse.note: I.e., Cyprus; but the term is probably used here generally, to refer to all the Mediterranean lands.

verse.text: And forces from him will arise and [note]1[/note]profane the sanctuary, [i]establishing[/i] the fortress and removing the daily [xref]a[/xref]sacrifice; and they will set up the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]abomination that desolates.
verse.note: The armies of Antiochus Epiphanes profaned the sanctuary, removed the daily sacrifice, and set up the abomination that desolates. Sacrifices, circumcision, and keeping the Sabbath were absolutely forbidden. Antiochus Epiphanes even went so far as to erect an altar to Zeus on the altar of burnt offering in the temple. Moreover, he set up his own image in the temple, sacrificed a sow on the altar, and sprinkled its blood in the temple. He forced the holy people to worship the idol and eat pork, and he seduced young men to commit fornication in the temple. In all these evils Antiochus Epiphanes typifies Antichrist, who will appear in the last week of the seventy weeks ([link]9:27[/link]; [link]Rev. 13:1-7[/link]). See note [link]27[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].[br/][br/]According to this book the great human image in [link]2:31-45[/link] destroys and desecrates the temple of God four times. The first time was by the head, Nebuchadnezzar ([link]1:1-2[/link]; [link]2 Chron. 36:18-19[/link]); the second time was by Antiochus Epiphanes, a descendant of one of the four generals of Alexander the Great's Grecian Empire ([link]8:9-14[/link]; [link]11:31-32[/link]); the third time was by Titus, a prince of the Roman Empire, in A.D. 70 ([link]9:26[/link]; [link]Matt. 24:2[/link]); and the fourth time will be by Antichrist, part of the ten toes of the restored Roman Empire, in the middle of the last seven years of this age ([link]9:27[/link]; [link]12:7[/link], [link]11[/link]). All these instances show that the center, the aim, and the goal of Satan's struggle against God is related to the temple, which typifies first Christ as God's embodiment ([link]John 2:19-21[/link]) and then the church, the Body of Christ, as the enlargement of Christ ([link]1 Cor. 3:16-17[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:20-22[/link]). God desires to have a place on earth where His people can worship Him, as a testimony that He still has an interest on this earth; but Satan is always struggling to destroy this place (cf. [link]Matt. 16:18[/link]; [link]John 2:19[/link]). Ultimately, as revealed in the New Testament, Satan will be fully destroyed ([link]Rev. 20:10[/link]), and the church as God's house ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link]), the mingling of God with His redeemed people, will be fully built up in Christ's resurrection and will consummate in the New Jerusalem as the center of the new heaven and the new earth for eternity ([link]Rev. 21-22[/link]).
Cf. note [link]15[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 24[/link].

verse.text: And with his smooth words he will cause those who act wickedly toward the covenant to be profane. But the [note]1[/note]people who know their God will show strength and take action.
verse.note: Referring to Judas Maccabeus and his people, who were encouraged and strengthened by this word in the book of Daniel to take action against Antiochus Epiphanes. The Maccabees defeated him and cleansed the temple. See notes [link chapter="8"]14[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]14[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]those with insight among the people will cause the many to understand; yet they will fall by sword and by flames, by captivity and by plundering for [i]some[/i] days.
verse.note: Or, the teachers of the people. So also until the end of the book. Antiochus Epiphanes persecuted and slew the devoted Jews ([link]vv. 33-35[/link]). In this also he typifies Antichrist, who will persecute and kill God's people at the end of this age ([link]Rev. 13:7[/link] and note).

verse.text: And when they fall, they will be helped with a little help; and many will join themselves to them in word only.

And some of those with insight will fall, in order to [xref]a[/xref]refine [note]1[/note]the people and to purify and cleanse [i]them,[/i] until the time of the [xref]b[/xref]end, for [i]the end[/i] is still at the appointed time.
verse.note: Lit., them.

verse.text: And the king will do as he pleases; and he will [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]exalt himself and magnify himself above every god, and against the God of gods he will speak extraordinary things; and he will prosper until the indignation is complete; for what has been determined will be done.
verse.note: See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in 2 Thes. 2[/link]. Whereas [link book="Dan." chapter="11"]vv. 21-35[/link] refer to Antiochus Epiphanes, the type, [link]vv. 36-45[/link] refer to Antichrist, the fulfillment (cf. [link]9:26-27[/link]). In this chapter there is a gap in the chronicle of history from the ending of the ruling of the four successors of Alexander the Great (from about the second half of the last century B.C., the time when the Roman Empire rose up to take the place of the kingdom of Greece and become the world power that will end the present age) to the last three and a half years of the present age. In this gap is the church age of mystery ([link]Eph. 3:3-11[/link]; [link]5:32[/link]).

verse.text: And he will not regard the gods of his fathers or the desire of women, [xref]a[/xref]nor will he regard any [i]other[/i] god; for he will magnify himself above all.
But he will honor instead the god of fortresses; indeed a god whom his fathers did not know he will honor with gold, silver, precious stones, and treasures.

And he will take action against the most fortified of fortresses with [i]the help of[/i] a foreign god; he will increase the honor of those who acknowledge [i]him[/i] and will cause them to rule over many, and he will divide the land [i]to them[/i] as a reward.

And at the time of the end the king of the south will push against him, and the king of the north will storm [i]back[/i] at him with chariots and horsemen and many ships; and he will enter the countries and overflow and pass through.

He will also enter the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]beautiful land, and many [i]countries[/i] will fall; but these will slip away from his hand: [xref]b[/xref]Edom, Moab, and the foremost of the children of Ammon.
verse.note: I.e., the land of Israel.

verse.text: Then he will stretch forth his hand against the countries, and for the land of Egypt there will be no escape.
And he will have control over the hidden stores of gold and silver and over all the precious things of the Egyptians; and the Libyans and [note]1[/note]Cushites will [i]follow[/i] in his steps.
verse.note: I.e., Ethiopians.

verse.text: But news from the east and from the north will trouble him, and he will go forth with great wrath destroying and exterminating many.

And he will pitch the tents of his palace between the sea and the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]beautiful holy mountain; but he will [note]2[/note]come to his [xref]b[/xref]end, and there will be no one to help him.
verse.note: Referring to Zion, where Jerusalem is.
Antichrist will come to his end when Christ as the stone cut out without hands comes with His bride to smash the great human image from the toes to the head ([link]2:34-35[/link] and notes).

verse.text: And at that [note]1[/note]time [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Michael, the great prince who stands for the children of your people, will arise; and there will be a time of [xref]b[/xref]distress, such as [xref]c[/xref]never occurred since there came to be a nation until that time; and at that time your people, every one found written in the [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]book, will be delivered.
verse.note: The time referred to here is the consummation of the age ([link]Matt. 28:20b[/link]), the last three and a half years of the present age ([link]v. 7[/link]; [link]7:25b[/link]). That will be a time of distress, the time of the great tribulation ([link]Jer. 30:7a[/link]; [link]Matt. 24:15-26[/link]), during which the shattering of the power of the holy people will be completed ([link]v. 7b[/link]; [link]7:25b[/link]; [link]Rev. 13:5[/link], [link]7a[/link]; [link]11:2[/link]). The vision in this chapter covers things in the last three and a half years of the present age, things in the kingdom age, and things in eternity.
See note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].

Those of the people of Israel who are found written in God's book of life will be delivered out of the hand of Antichrist. When Christ comes back to set up the kingdom, the small number of remaining Jews, the remnant of Israel ([link]Zech. 13:8-14:2[/link] and notes), will see Christ descending in the air and will repent, receive Him, and be saved and regenerated ([link]Zech. 12:10-14[/link]; [link]14:4-5[/link]; [link]Matt. 24:30[/link]; [link]Rom. 11:26-27[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:7[/link]). However, because they will be the later believers, they will not participate in the heavenly section of the kingdom as kings and priests, but rather will be kept on the earth to be the priests of God ([link]Isa. 2:2-3[/link]; [link]Zech. 8:20-23[/link]) in the earthly section of the thousand-year kingdom. See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 3[/link].[br/][br/]In the millennial kingdom there will be three groups of people: (1) the overcoming believers in the heavenly section as kings and priests in the heavenlies (see note [link]6[sup]4[/sup] in Rev. 20[/link]); (2) the saved Jews who will be on the earth as the priests teaching the restored nations (see note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Zech. 8[/link]); and (3) the restored nations as the citizens under the ruling of the overcoming believers as the co-kings of Christ and also under the teaching and care of the saved Jews (see notes [link book="Matt." chapter="25"]32[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]34[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 25[/link]). After the thousand years of the age of the kingdom, the old heaven and the old earth will be burned in order to be renewed ([link]2 Pet. 3:12-13[/link] and notes) and become a new heaven and new earth ([link]Rev. 21:1[/link]). At that time the Jews who are saved and regenerated by the Lord in His second coming will join all the believing saints of the Old Testament age and the New Testament age to be the New Jerusalem as God's dwelling place and expression for eternity ([link]Rev. 21:12[/link], [link]14[/link]). The nations who remain at the end of the millennium will be transferred to the land in the new earth to be the citizens forever ([link]Rev. 21:24-26[/link]; [link]22:2b[/link]). That will be the eternal kingdom of God, in which God's chosen, created, regenerated, sanctified, transformed, and glorified people, who are one with God for eternity, will rule over and teach the restored (but not regenerated) nations, who will be the citizens in the new heaven and the new earth. Eventually, in eternity in His eternal kingdom God will have His priests, His kings, and His people ([link]Rev. 22:3[/link], [link]5[/link]; [link]21:3[/link]) forever.

verse.text: And many of those who are [xref]a[/xref]sleeping in the dust of the ground will [xref]b[/xref]awake, some to [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]life eternal and some to reproach, to [note]1[/note]eternal contempt.
verse.note: At the end of the great tribulation the sleeping (i.e., dead — [link]1 Cor. 15:51[/link]) saints will rise in the resurrection of life to meet with Christ in the air ([link]vv. 2a[/link], [link]13[/link]; [link]John 5:28-29a[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 4:16-17[/link]; [link]2 Thes. 2:1[/link], [link]3-4[/link], [link]8[/link]; [link]Rev. 14:14-16[/link]). After the millennium, the kingdom age, those who died as unbelievers will rise in the resurrection of judgment and will suffer eternal reproach and contempt in eternity forever and ever ([link]v. 2b[/link]; [link]John 5:29b[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:15[/link]).

verse.text: And those who have insight will [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]shine like the shining of the heavenly expanse, and those who turn many to righteousness, like the [xref]b[/xref]stars, forever and ever.
verse.note: The overcomers mentioned in this verse will shine in the kingdom age ([link]Matt. 13:43[/link]). Together with those in [link]v. 10[/link] and with Daniel in [link]v. 13[/link], they will participate in the kingdom and will continue their enjoyment of the eternal life in eternity forever.

verse.text: But you, Daniel, shut up the words and [xref]a[/xref]seal the book until the time of the [xref]b[/xref]end; many will go here and there, and knowledge will be increased.
Then I, Daniel, looked, and there were two others standing, one on this bank of the river and the other on that bank of the river.
And one said to the man clothed in [xref]a[/xref]linen, who was above the water of the river, How long [i]will it be[/i] until the end of these wonders?

And I heard the man clothed in linen, who was above the water of the river, as He lifted up His right [xref]a[/xref]hand and His left hand to heaven and swore by Him who lives forever that there would be [note]1[/note]a [xref]b[/xref]time and times and half [i]a time;[/i] and when the shattering of the power of the holy people is completed, all these things will be [xref]c[/xref]completed.
verse.note: See note [link]25[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].

verse.text: And I heard, but I did not understand. Then I said, Lord, what will the latter end of these things be?
And He said, Go [i]your way,[/i] Daniel, for the words are shut up and sealed until the time of the [xref]a[/xref]end.
Many will be purified, [note]1[/note]cleansed, and [xref]a[/xref]refined, but the wicked will act wickedly; and none of the wicked will understand, but those who have insight will understand.
verse.note: Lit., whitened.

verse.text: And from the time that the [note]1[/note]daily [xref]a[/xref]sacrifice is removed and the [xref]b[/xref]abomination that desolates is set up, [i]there will be[/i] a [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]thousand two hundred and ninety days.
verse.note: See note [link]27[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

At the end of the one thousand two hundred and sixty days of the great tribulation Antichrist will be fully destroyed by Christ ([link]2 Thes. 2:8[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:20[/link]). At the beginning of the millennium, the kingdom age, thirty more days will be needed to cleanse and clear up the contaminated, devastated, and defiled temple. Just as the Maccabees cleansed the temple after it had been defiled by Antiochus Epiphanes ([link]8:14[/link] and notes), so the saved Jews will cleanse the temple at the beginning of the millennial kingdom.

verse.text: Blessed is he who waits and reaches the [note]1[/note]thousand three hundred and thirty-five days!
verse.note: After the cleansing of the temple mentioned in [link]v. 11[/link], forty-five days will be needed to recover the destroyed system of the worship of God with the daily sacrifices. Thus, from the time that Antichrist causes the offerings to cease to the day the Israelites enjoy the offerings again will be 1335 days. The restoration of the sacrifices will be a great blessing to the people of Israel ([link]Joel 2:14[/link]).

verse.text: But you, go [i]your way[/i] until the end, and you will [xref]a[/xref]rest and [note]1[/note]rise [i]again[/i] in your lot at the [xref]b[/xref]end of the days.
verse.note: Indicating that Daniel will be resurrected to enjoy his lot in the kingdom age. See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup][/link].
